sourceDesc.p: From the LION version of STC16680, 1598, checked against page images from EEBO of the same edition. The earlier edition, STC16679, 1594, was not available from LION.

Play details
A looking glasse for London and England. Genre: Moralities. Date first published: 1594. Date first performed: 1587-1588.

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

body.stage: Enters Rasni king of Niniuie, with three kings of Cicilia, Creet, and Paphlagonia, from the ouerthrow of Ieroboam, King of Ierusalem.

sp.l: So pace ye on triumphant warriors,
Make Venus Lemmo armed in all his pomp,
Bash at the brightness of your hardy looks,
For you the Viceroys and the Cavaliers,
That wait on Rasnies royal mightiness:
Boast petty kings, and glory in your fates,
That stars have made your fortunes clime so high,
To give attend on Rasnies excellency.
Am I not he that rules great Niniuie,
Rounded with Lycas silver flowing streams,
Whose City large Diametri contains,
Even three days journeys length from wall to wall,
Two hundredth gates carved out of burnished brass,
As glorious as the porthole of the Sun,
And for to deck heavens battlements with pride,
Six hundredth Towers that topless touch the clouds:
This City is the footstool of your King,
A hundredth Lords do honour at my feet,
My sceptre straineth both the parallels,
And now to enlarge the highness of my power,
I have made Iudeas Monarch flee the field,
And beat proud Ieroboam from his holds,
Winning from Cades to Samaria,
Great Jewry's God that foiled stout Benhadab,
Could not rebate the strength that Rasni brought,
For be he God in heaven, yet Viceroys know,
Rasni is God on earth and none but he.

sp.speaker: Cicilia
sp.l: If lovely shape, feature by natures skill,
Passing in beauty fair Endymions,
That Luna wrapped within her snowy breasts,
Or that sweet boy that wrought bright Venus bane,
Transformed unto a purple Hyacinth,
If beauty Nonpareil in excellence,
May make a King match with the Gods in degree,
Rasni is God on earth, and none but he.

sp.speaker: Creet,
sp.l: If martial looks wrapped in a cloud of wars
More fierce than Mars, lighteneth from his eyes
Sparkling revenge and dire disparagement:
If doughty deeds more haughty than any done,
Sealed with the smile of fortune and of fate,
Matchless to manage Lance and Curtelex.
If such high actions graced with victories,
May make a King match with the Gods in degree,
Rasni is God on earth, and none but he.

sp.speaker: Paphlag.
sp.l: If Pallas wealth.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Viceroys enough, Paphlagon no more,
See where is my sister fair Remilia,
Fairer than was the virgin Dania,
That waits on Venus with a golden show,
She that hath stolen the wealth of Rasnes looks,
And tide his thoughts within her lovely locks,
She that is loved, and love unto your King,
See where she comes to gratulate my fame.

body.stage: Enters Radagon with Remilia, sister to Rasni, Aluia wife to Paphlagon, and other Ladies, bring a Globe seated in a ship.

sp.speaker: Remilia.
sp.l: Victorious Monarch, second unto Jove,
Mars upon earth, and Neptune on the Seas,
Whose frown stroys all the Ocean with a calm,
Whose smile, draws Flora to display her pride,
Whose eye holds wanton Venus at a gaze,
Rasni the Regent of great Niniuie,
For thou hast foiled proud Ieroboams force,
And like the mustering breath of olus,
That overturns the pines of Libanon,
Hast scattered Jewry and her upstart grooms,
Winning from Cades to Samaria,
Remilia greets thee with a kind salute,
And for a present to thy mightiness,
Gives thee a Globe folded within a ship,
As King on earth, and Lord of all the Seas,
With such a welcome unto Niniuie
As may thy sisters humble love afford.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Sister. The title fits not thy degree,
A higher state of honour shall be thine,
The lovely Trull that Mercury entrapped,
Within the curious pleasure of his tongue,
And she that bashed the sun god with her eyes,
Fair Semele the choice of Venus maids,
Were not so beauteous as Remilia.
Then sweating, sister shall not serve the turn,
But Rasnes wife, his Lemmon and his love.
Thou shalt like Juno wed thy thyself to Jove,
And fold me in the riches of thy fair,
Remilia shall be Rasnes Paramour.
For why if I be Mars for warlike deeds,
And though bright Venus for thy clear aspect,
Why should not from our loins issue a son,
That might be Lord of royal sovereignty?
Of twenty worlds, if twenty worlds might be,
What sayst Remilia art thou Rasnes wife?

sp.speaker: Remilia.
sp.l: My heart doth swell with favour of thy thoughts,
The love of Rasni maketh me as proud
As Juno when she wore heavens Diadem.
Thy sister borne, was for thy wife by love,
Had I the riches nature locketh up,
To deck her darling, beauty when she smiles,
Rasni should prank him in the pride of all.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Remelias love, is far more either prized,
Than Ieroboams or the worlds subdue,
Lordings, I will have my weddings sumptuous,
Made glorious with the treasures of the world,
I will fetch from Albia shelves of Margarites,
And strip the Indies of their Diamonds,
And Tyre shall yield me tribute of her gold,
To make Remelias wedding glorious,
I will send for all the Damoiselle Queens that live
Within the reach of Rasnies government,
To wait as hand maids to Remelia,
That her attendant train may pass the troupe
That gloried Venus at her wedding day.

sp.speaker: Creete.
sp.l: O my Lord, not sister to thy love,
"It is incest and too foul a fact for Kings,
Nature allows no limits to such lust.

sp.speaker: Rada.
sp.l: Presumptuous Viceroy, darest thou check thy Lord,
Or twit him with the laws that nature loves,
Is not great Rasni above natures reach,
God upon earth, and all his will is law.

sp.speaker: Creet.
sp.l: O flatter not, for hateful is his choice,
And sisters love will blemish all his worth.

sp.speaker: Radag.
sp.l: Doth not the brightness of his majesty,
Shadow his deeds from being counted faults.

sp.speaker: Rasni
sp.l: Well hast thou answered within Radon,
I like thee for thy learned Sophistry,
But thou of Creet, that countercheckest thy King,
Pack hence in exile, give Radagon thy Crown,
Be thee Vicegerent of his royalty?
And fail me not in what my thoughts may please,
For from a beggar have I brought thee up,
And graced thee with the honour of a Crown,
Ye quondam king, what feed ye on delays?

sp.speaker: Creete.
sp.l: Better no King than Viceroy under him
That hath no virtue to maintain his Crown.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Remilias, what fair dames be those that wait
Attendant on my matchless royalty?

sp.speaker: Remilia.
sp.l: It is Aluia, the fair wife to the king of Paphlagonia.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Trust me she is a fair: thou hast Paphlagon a Jewel,
To fold thee in so bright a sweetings arms.

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: Like you her my Lord?

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: What if I do Radagon?

sp.speaker: Rada.
sp.l: Why then she is yours my Lord, for marriage
Makes no exception, where Rasni doth command.

sp.speaker: Paphla.
sp.l: Ill dost thou counsel him to fancy wives.

sp.speaker: Rada.
sp.l: Wife or not wife, what so he likes is his.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: well answered Radagon thou art for me,
Feed thou mine humour, and be still a king.
Lords go in triumph of my happy loves,
And for to feast us after all our broils,
Frolic and revel it in Niniuie
Whatsoever befitteth your conceited thoughts,
Or good or ill, love or not love my boys,
In love, or what may satisfy your lust,
Act it my Lords, for no man dare say no.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.l: Denesum imperium, Cum Jove nunc teno.

body.stage: Enters brought in by an Angell Oseas the Prophet, and set downe ouer the Stage in a Throne.

sp.speaker: Angell.
sp.l: Amaze not man of God, if in the spirit
Thy art brought from Jewry unto Niniuie,
So was Elias wrapped within a storm,
And set upon mount Carnell by the Lord,
For thou hast preached long to the stubborn Jews,
Whose flinty hearts have felt no sweet remorse,
But lightly valuing all the threats of God,
Have still persevered in their wickedness.
Lo I have brought thee unto Niniuie,
The rich and royal City of the world,
Pampered in wealth, and overgrown with pride,
As Sodome and Gomorrha full of sin,
The Lord looks down and cannot see one good,
Not one that covets to obey his will,
But wicked all, from Cradle to the Church.
Note then Oseas all their grievous sins,
And see the wrath of God that pays revenge.
And when the ripeness of their sin is full,
And thou hast written all their wicked through,
I will carry thee to Jewry, back again,
And seat thee in the great Jerusalem,
There shalt thou publish in her open streets,
That God sends down his hateful wrath for sin,
On such as never heard his Prophets speak ,
Much more will he inflict a world of plagues,
On such as hear the sweetness of his voice,
And yet obey not what his Prophets speak,
Sit thee Oseas pondering in the spirit,
The mightiness of these fond peoples sins,

sp.speaker: Oseas.
sp.l: The will of the Lord be done.

body.stage: Enters the Clowne and his crew of Ruffians, to go to drinke.

sp.speaker: Ruffian.
sp.p: Come on Smith, thou shalt be one one of the crew, because thou knowest where the best Ale in the Town is.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Come on, in faith my colts, I have left my Master. striking of a heat, and stole away, because I would keep you company.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Why, what shall we have this paltry Smith with us?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Paltry Smith, why you incarnative knave, what are you, that you speak petty treason against the Smiths trade?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: Why slave, I am a gentleman of Niniuie.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: A Gentleman good sir, I remember you well and all your progenitors, your father bare office in our town, an honest man he was, and in great discredit in the parish, for they bestowed two squires livings on him, the one was on working days, and then he kept the town stage, and on holidays they made him the Sextons man, for he whipped dogs out of the Church. Alas sir, your father, why sir methinks I see the Gentleman still, a proper youth he was faith, aged some four and ten, his beard Rats colour, half black, half white, his nose was in the highest degree of noses, it was nose Autem glorificam, so set with Rubies, that after his death it should have been nailed up in Copper-smiths hall for a monument. Well sir, I was beholding to your good father, for he was the first man that ever instructed me in the mystery of a pot of Ale.
Well said Smith, that crossed him over the thumbs.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Villain were it not that we go to be merry, my rapier should presently quit thy opprobrious terms.

sp.speaker: Smith
sp.p: O Peter, Peter put up thy sword I prithee heartily into thy scabbard, hold in your rapier, for though I have not a long reacher, I have a short hitter. Nay then gentlemen stay me, for my choler begins to rise against him: for mark the words of a paltry Smith, O horrible sentence, thou hast in these words I will stand to it, libelled against all the sound horses, whole horses, sore horses, Coursers, Curtals, Jades, Cuts, Hackneys, and Mares: whereupon my friend, in their defence, I give thee this curse, thou shalt be worth a horse of thine own this seven year.

sp.l: Clown. I prithee Smith is your occupation so excellent?

sp.speaker: Smith
sp.p: A paltry Smith, why I will stand to it, a Smith is Lord of the four elements, for our iron is made of the earth, our bellows blow out air, our floor holds fire, and our forge water. Nay sir, we read in the Chronicles, that there was a God of our occupation.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: Aye , but he was a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Smith
sp.p: That was the reason sir he called your father cousin, paltry smith, why in this one word thou hast defaced their worshipful occupation.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Smith
sp.p: Marry sir I will stand to it, that a Smith in his kind is a Physician, a Surgeon and a Barber. For let a Horse take a cold, or be troubled with the bots, and we straight give him a potion or a purgation, in such physical manner that he mends straight, if he have outward diseases, as the spewing, splent, ring bone, windgall or fashion, or sir a galled back, we let him blood and clap a plaster to him with a pestilence, that mends him with a very vengeance, now if his mane grow out of order, and he have any rebellious hairs, we straight to our shears and trim him with what cut it please us, pick his ears and make him neat, marry indeed sir, we are slovens for one thing, we never use any musk balls to wash him with, and the reason is sir, because he can woe without kissing.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: Well sirrah, leave off these praises of a Smith, and bring us to the best Ale in the town.

sp.speaker: Smith
sp.p: Now sir I have a feat above all the Smiths in Niniuie for sir, I am a Philosopher that can dispute of the nature of Ale, for mark you sir, a pot of ale consists of four parts, Imprimis the Ale, the Toast, the Ginger and the Nutmeg.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Smith
sp.p: The Ale is a restorative, bread is a binder, mark you sir two excellent points in physic, the Ginger, o ware of that: the philosophers have written of the nature of ginger, it is expulsitive in two degrees, you shall hear the sentence of Galen it will make a man belch, cough, and fart, and is a great comfort to the heart, a proper poesy I promise you, but now to the noble virtue of the Nutmeg, it is saith one Ballad I think an English Roman was the author, an underlayer to the brains, for when the Ale gives a buffet to the head, o the Nutmeg that keeps him for a while in temper.
Thus you see the description of the virtue of a pot of Ale, now sir to put my physical precepts in practise follow me, but before I step any further.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: What is the matter now?

sp.speaker: Smith
sp.p: Why seeing I have provided the Ale, who is the purveyor for the wenches, for masters take this of me, a cup of Ale without a wench, why alas it is like an egg without salt, or a red herring without mustard.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.p: Lead us to the Ale, we will have wenches enough I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Oseas.
sp.l: Iniquity seeks out companions still,
And mortal men are armed to do ill:
London look on, this matter nips thee near,
Leave off thy riot, pride and sumptuous cheer.
Spend less at board, and spare not at the door,
But aid the infant, and relieve the poor.
Else seeking mercy, being merciless,
Thou be adjudged to endless heaviness.

body.stage: Enters the Vsurer, a yoong Gentleman, and a poore man.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: Come on, I am every day troubled with those needy companions, what news with you, what wind brings you hither?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Sir I hope how far soever you make it off, you remember too well for me, that this is the day wherein I should pay you money that I took up of you a-late in a commodity.

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.p: And sir, sir-reverence of your manhood and gentry, I have brought home such money as you lent me.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: You young Gentleman, is my money ready?

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.p: Truly sir, this time was so short, the commodity so bad, and the promise of friends so broken, that I could not provide it against the day, wherefore I am come to entreat you to stand my friend, and to favour me with a longer time, and I will make you sufficient consideration.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: Is the wind in that door, if thou hast my money so it is, I will not defer a day, an hour, a minute, but take the forfeit of the bond.

sp.speaker: Gent/
sp.p: I pray you sir consider that my loss was great by the commodity I took up, you know sir I borrowed of you forty pounds, whereof I had ten pounds in money, and thirty pounds in Lute strings, which when I came to sell again, I could get but five pounds for them, so had I sir but fifteen pounds for my forty: In consideration of this ill bargain, I pray you sir give me a month longer.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: I answered thee afore not a minute, what have I to do how thy bargain proved, I have thy hand set to my book, that thou receivedest forty pounds of me in money.

sp.speaker: Gent/
sp.p: Aye sir it was your device that, to colour the Statute, but your conscience knows what I had.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: Friend, thou speakest hebrew to him, when thou talkest to him of conscience, for he hath as much conscience about the forfeit of an Obligation, as my blind Mare God bless her, hath over a manger of Oats.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Then there is no favour sir?

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: Come tomorrow to me, and see how I will use thee.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: No covetous Caterpillar, know, that I have made extreme shift rather than I would fall into the hands of such a ravening panther: and therefore here is thy money and deliver me the recognisance of my lands.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: What a spite is this, hath sped of his Crowns, if he had missed but one half hour, what a goodly Farm had I gotten for forty pounds, well it is my cursed fortune. O have I no shift to make him forfeit his recognisance.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Come sir will you dispatch and tell your money?

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: Stay, what is this a clock four, let me see, to be paid between the hours of three and four in the afternoon, this goes right for me: you sir, hear you not the clock, and have you not a counterpane of your Obligation? the hour is past, it was to be paid between three and four, and now the clock hath strucken four, I will receive none, I will stand to the forfeit of the recognisance.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Why sir, I hope you do but jest, why it is but four, and will you for a minute take forfeit of my bond? if it were so sir, I was here before four.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: Why didst thou not tender thy money then? if I offer thee injuries, eke the law of me, complain to the judge, I will receive no money.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: Well sir, I hope you will stand my good master for my Cow, I borrowed thirty shillings on her, and for that I have paid you eighteen pence a week, and for her meat you have had her milk, and I tell you sir, she gives a pretty soap: now sir here is your money.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: Hang beggarly knave, comest to me for a Cow, did I not bind her bought and sold for a penny, and was not thy day to have paid yesterday? thou gettest no Cow at my hand.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: No cow sir, alas that word no cow, goes as cold to my heart, as a draught of small drink in a frosty morning. No cow sir, why alas, alas, Master. Usurer, what shall become of me, my wife, and my poor child?

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: Thou gettest no cow of me knave, I cannot stand prating with you, I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: Nay but hear you Master. Usurer, no cow, why sir here is your thirty shillings, I have paid you eighteen pence a week, and therefore there is reason I should have my cow.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.l: What pratest thou, have I not answered thee thy day is broken?

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: Why sir alas, my Cow is a common wealth to me, for first sir, she allows me, my wife and son, for to banquet ourselves withal, butter, cheese, whey, curds, cream, sod milk, raw milk, sour milk, sweet milk, and butter-milk, besides sir, she saved me every year a penny in almanacs, for she was as good to me as a Prognostication, if she had but set up her tail and have galloped about the mead, my little boy was able to say, O father there will be a storm: her very tail was a Calendar to me, and now to lose my cow, alas Master. Usurer, take pity upon me.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: I have other matters to talk on, farewell fellows.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Why but thou covetous churl, wilt thou not receive thy money and deliver me my recognisance?

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: I will deliver thee none, if I have wronged thee, seek thy mends at the law.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: And so I will insatiable peasant.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: And sir, rather then I will put up this word no Cow, I will lay my wives best gown to pawn. I tell you sir, when the slave uttered this word no Cow, it struck to my heart, for my wife shall never have one so fit for her turn again, for indeed sir, she is a woman that hath her twiddling strings broke.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What meanest thou by that fellow?

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: Marry sir, sir-reverence of your manhood, she breaks wind behind , and indeed sir, when she sat milking of her Cow and let a fart, my other Cows would start at the noise, and kick down the milk and away: but this Cow, sir the gentlest Cow, my wife might blow whilst she burst: and having such good conditions, shall the Usurer come upon me with no cow? Nay sir, before I pocket up this word no Cow, my wives gown goes to the Lawyer, why alas sir, it is as ill a word to me, as no Crown to a King.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Well fellow, go with me, and I will help thee to a Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.l: Marry and I will sir: no Cow, well the world goes hard.

sp.speaker: Oseas.
sp.l: Where hateful usury
Is counted husbandry,
Where merciless men rob the poor,
And the needy are thrust out of door.
Where gain is held for conscience,
And men's pleasures is all on pence,
Where young Gentlemen forfeit their lands
Through riot, into the Usurers hands:
Where poverty is despised and pity banished
And mercy indeed utterly vanished.
Where men esteem more of money than of God,
Let that land look to feel his wrathful rod.
For there is no sin more odious in his sight,
Than where usury defrauds the poor of his right.
London take heed, these sins abound in thee:
The poor complain, the widows wronged be.
The Gentlemen by subtlety are spoiled,
The ploughmen lose the crop for which they toiled.
Sin reigns in thee O London every hour,
Repent and tempt not thus the heavenly power.

body.stage: Enters Remilia, with a traine of Ladies in all royaltie.

sp.speaker: Remilia.
sp.l: Fair Queen, yet handmaids unto Rasnes love,
Tell me, is not my state so glorious
As Juno's pomp, when tired with heavens despoil,
Clad in her vestments, spotted all with stars?
She crossed the silver path unto her Jove
Is not Remilias far more beauteous,
Rich with the pride of natures excellency?
Than Venus in the brightest of her shine?
My hairs surpass they not Apollos locks?
Are not my Tresses curled with such art,
As love delights to hide him in their fair?
Doth not mine eye shine like the morning lamp,
That tells Aurera when her love will come?
Have I not stolen the beauty of the heavens,
And placest it on the feature of my face?
Can any Goddess make compare with me?
Or match her with the fair Remilia

sp.speaker: Aluida.
sp.l: The beauties that proud Paris saw from Troy,
Mustering in Ida for the golden ball,
Were not so gorgeous as Remilia.

sp.speaker: Remilia.
sp.l: I have tricked my trammels up with riches balm,
And made my perfumes of the purest Myrrh:
The precious drugs that Egypt's wealth affords,
The costly painting fetched from curious Tyre,
Have mended in my face what nature missed.
Am I not the earths wonder in my looks?

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: The wonder of the earth and pride of heaven.

sp.speaker: Remilia.
sp.l: Look Aluida a hair stands not amiss,
For women's locks are trammels of conceit,
Which do entangle love for all his wiles.

sp.speaker: Aluid.
sp.l: Madam, unless you coy it trick and trim,
And play the civil wanton ere you yield,
Smiting disdain of pleasures with your tongue,
Patting your princely Rasni on the cheek,
When he presumes to kiss without consent:
You mar the market, beauty naught avails.
You must be proud, for pleasures hardly got,
Are sweet, if once attained.

sp.speaker: Remilia.
sp.l: Fair Aluida,
Thy counsel makes Remilia passing wise.
Suppose that thou wert Rasnes mightiness,
And I Remilia Prince of excellence.

sp.speaker: Aluida.
sp.l: I would be master then of love and thee.

sp.speaker: Remil.
sp.l: Of love and me? Proud and disdainful king,
Darest thou presume to touch a Deity,
Before she grace thee with a yielding smile?

sp.speaker: Aluida.
sp.l: Tut my Remilia, be not thou so coy,
Say nay, and take it.

sp.speaker: Remilia.
sp.l: Careless and unkind,
Talks Rasni to Remilia in such sort
As if he did enjoy a human form?
Look on thy Love, behold mine eyes divine,
And darest thou twit me with a woman's fault?
Ah Rasni thou art rash to judge of me,
I tell thee Flora oft hath wooed my lips,
To lend a rose to beautify her spring,
The sea Nymphs fetch their lilies from my cheeks.
Then thou unkind, and hereon would I weep.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: And here would Aluida resign her charge,
For were I but in thought The Assirian King,
I needs must quite thy tears, with kisses sweet,
And crave a pardon with a friendly touch,
You know it Madam though I teach it not,
The touch I mean, you smile when as you think it.

sp.speaker: Remi.
sp.l: How am I pleased to hear thy pretty prate,
According to the humour of my mind?
Ah Nymphs, who fairer than Remilia?
The gentle winds have wood me with their sighs,
The frowning air hath cleared when I did smile,
And when I tract upon the grass,
Love that makes warm the centre of the earth,
Lift up his crest to kiss Remilas foot,
Juno still entertains her amorous Jove
With new delights, for fear he look on me,
The Phoenix feathers are become my Fan,
For I am beauties Phoenix in this world.
Shut close these Curtains straight and shadow me,
For fear Apollo spy me in his walks,
And scorn all eyes, to see Remilias eyes.
Nymphs, Eunuchs, sing for Mauors draweth nigh,
Hide me in Closure, let him long to look,
For were a Goddess fairer than am I,
I will scale the heavens to pull her from the place.

body.stage: They draw the Curtaines, and Musicke plaies.

sp.speaker: Aluida.
sp.l: Believe me, though she say that she is fairest,
I think my penny silver by her leave.

body.stage: Enter Rasni with his Lords in pomp, who make a ward about him, with him the Magi in great pomp.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Magi for love of Rasni by our Art,
By Magic frame an Armour out of hand,
For fair Remilia to disport her in.
Meanwhile, I will bethink me on further, a pomp.
sp.stage: The Magi with their rods beate the ground, and from vnder the same riseth a braue Arbour, the King returneth in an other sute while the Trumpets sounde.
sp.l: Blessed be ye man of Art that grace me thus,
And blessed be this day where Himen hies,
To join in union pride of heaven and earth.
sp.stage: Lightning and thunder wherewith Remelia is strooken.
sp.l: What wondrous threatening noise is this I hear?
What flashing lightnings trouble our delights?
When I draw near Remilias royal Tent,
I waking, dream of sorrow or mishap.

sp.speaker: Rada.
sp.l: Dread not O King, at ordinary chance,
These are but common exaltations,
Drawn from the earth, in substance hot and dry,
Or moist and thick, or Meteors combust,
Matters and causes incident to time,
In kindling in the fiery region first.
Tut, be not now a Roman Augerer,
Approach the Tent, look on Remelia.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Thou hast confirmed my doubts kind Radagon.
Now ope ye folds where Queen of favour sits
Carrying a Net within her curled locks,
Wherein the Graces are entangled oft:
Ope like the imperial gates where Phoebus sits,
When as he means to woo his Clitia:
Nocturnal cares, ye blemishers of bliss,
Cloud not mine eyes whilst I behold her face,
Remilia my delight, she answereth not.

body.stage: He drawes the Curtaines and findes her strooken with Thunder, blacke.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: How pale? as if bereaved in fatal meeds,
The balmy breath hath left her bosom quite.
My Hesperus by cloudy death is bent,
Villains away, fetch Syrups of the Inde,
Fetch Balsomo the kind preserve of life,
Fetch wine of Greece fetch oils, fetch herbs, fetch all
To fetch her life, or I will faint and die.
sp.stage: They bring in all these and offer, nought preuailes.
sp.l: Herbs, Oils of Inde alas there naught prevails.
Shut are the day bright eyes, that made me see,
Locked are the gems of joy in dens of death,
Yet triumph I on fate, and he on her.
Malicious mistress of inconstancy,
Damned be thy name, that hath obscured my joy,
Kings, Viceroy, Princes, rear a royal tomb
For my Remelia bear her from my sight,
Whilst I in tears, weep for Remilia.

sp.speaker: Rada.
sp.l: What maketh Rasni moody? Loss of one?
As if no more were left so fair as she?
Behold a dainty minion for the nonce,
Fair Aluida the Paphlagonian Queen,
Woo her, and leave this weeping for the dead.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.l: What woo my subjects wife that honoureth me?

sp.speaker: Rada.
sp.l: Tut, Kings this meum tuum should not know.
Is she not fair? Is not her husband hence?
Hold, take her at the hands of Radagon.
A pretty peat to drive your mourn away.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: She smiles on me, I see she is mine own.
Wilt thou be Rasnes royal Paramour?

sp.speaker: Rad.
sp.l: She blushing yields consent, make no dispute?
The King is sad, and must be gladded straight.
Let Paphlagonian King go mourn meanwhile.

body.stage: He thrust the King out, and so they Exeunt

sp.speaker: Oseas.
sp.l: Pride hath his judgment, London look about,
It is not enough in show to be devout:
A fury now from heaven to lands unknown,
Hath made the Prophet speak, not to his own.
Fly wanton fly, this pride and vain attire,
The seals to set your tender hearts on fire.
Be faithful in the promise you have past,
Else God will plague and punish at the last.
When lust is hid in shroud of wretched life,
When craft doth dwell in bed of married wife.
Mark but the Prophets, we that shortly shows,
After death expect for many woes.

body.stage: Enters the poore man and the Gntleman, with their Lawier.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I need not sir discourse unto you, the duty of Lawyers in tendering the right cause of their Clients, nor the conscience you are tied unto by higher command. Therefore suffice the Usurer hath done me wrong, you know the case: and good sir, I have strained myself to give you your fees.

sp.speaker: Lawier.
sp.p: Sir if I should any way neglect so manifest a truth, I were to be accused of open perjury, for the case is evident.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: And truly sir, for my case, if you help me not for my matter, why sir, I and my wife are quite undone, I want my mease of milk when I go to my work, and my boy his bread and butter when he goes to school. Master. Lawyer pity me, for surely sir, I was fain to lay my wives best gown to pawn for your fees, when I looked upon it sir, and saw how handsomely it was daubed with statute lace, and what a fair mockado Cape it had, and then thought how handsomely it became my wife, truly sir my heart is made of butter, it melts at the least persecution, I fell on weeping, but when I thought on the words the Usurer gave me, no Cow: then sir, I would have stripped her into her smock, but I would make him deliver my Cow ere I had done, therefore good Master. Lawyer stand my friend.

sp.speaker: Lawier.
sp.p: Trust me father, I will do for thee as much as for myself.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.l: Are you married sir?

sp.speaker: Lawier.
sp.l: Aye marry am I father.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: Then goods Benison light on you and your good wife, and send her that she be never troubled with my wives disease.

sp.speaker: Lawier.
sp.l: Why what is thy wives disease?

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: Truly sir, she hath two open faults, and one privy fault, sir the first is, she is too eloquent for a poor man, and hath he words of Art, for she will call me Rascal, Rogue, Runagate, Varlet, Vagabond, Slave, and Knave. Why alas sir, and these be but holiday terms, but if you heard her working-day words, in faith sir, they be rattlers like thunder sir, for after the dew follows a storm, for then am I sure either to be well buffeted, my face scratched, or my head broken, and therefore good Master. Lawyer, on my knees I ask it, let me not go home again to my wife, with this word, No Cow: for then she will exercise her two faults upon me with all extremity.

sp.speaker: Lawier.
sp.l: Fear not man, but what is thy wives privy fault?

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: Truly sir, that is a thing of nothing, alas she indeed sir-reverence of your mastership, doth use to break wind in her sleep. O sir, here comes the judge, and the old Caitiff the Usurer

body.stage: Enters the Iudge, the Vsurer, and his attendants.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: Sir here is forty Angels for you, and if at any time you want a hundredth pound or two, it is ready at your command, or the feeding of three or four fat bullocks: whereas these needy slaves can reward with nothing but a cap and a knee, and therefore I pray you sir favour my case.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.l: Fear not sir, I will do what I can for you.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.l: What master Lawyer, what make you here, mine adversary for these Clients?

sp.speaker: Lawier.
sp.l: So it chanceth now sir.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: I know you know the old Proverb, He is not wise, that is not wise for himself. I would not be disgraced in this action, therefore here is twenty angels say nothing in the matter, and what you say, say to no purpose, for the Judge is my friend.

sp.speaker: Lawier.
sp.l: Let me alone, I will fit your purpose.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.p: Come, where are these fellows that are the plaintiffs, what can they say against this honest Citizen our neighbour, a man of good report amongst all men?

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: Truly Master. Judge, he is a man much spoken of , marry every man's cries are against him, and especially we, and therefore I think we have brought our Lawyer to touch him with as much law as will fetch his lands and my Cow, with a pestilence.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Sir, I am the other plaintiff, and this is my councellor, I beseech your honour be favourable to me in equity.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.p: O Seignior Mizaldo, what can you say in this Gentleman's behalf?

sp.speaker: Lawier.
sp.p: Faith sir as yet little good, sir tell you your own case to the judge, for I have so many matters in my head, that I have almost forgotten it.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Is the wind in that door? why then my Lord thus: I took up of this cursed Usurer, for so I may well term him, a commodity of forty pounds, whereof I received ten pound in money, and thirty pound in lute strings, whereof I could by great friendship make but five pounds: for the assurance of this bad commodity, I bound him my land in recognisance, I came at my day and tendered him his money and he would not take it, for the redress of my open wrong, I crave but justice.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.l: What say you to this sir?

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: That first, he had no Lute strings of me, for look you sir, I have his own hand to my book for the receipt of forty pound.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: That was sir, but a device of him to colour the Statute.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.p: Well he hath thine own hand, and we can crave no more in law: but now sir, he says his money was tendered at the day and hour.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: This is manifest contrary sir, and on that I will depose, for here is the obligation, to be paid between three and four in the afternoon, and the Clock struck four before he offered it, and the words be between three and four, therefore to be tendered before four.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Sir, I was there before four, and he held me with brabbling till the Clock struck, and then for the breach of a minute he refused my money, and keep the recognisance of my land for so small a trifle: Good Seignior Mizaldo speak what is law, you have your fee, you have heard what the case is, and therefore do me justice and right: I am a young Gentleman, and speak for my patrimony.

sp.speaker: Lawier.
sp.p: Faith sir, the Case is altered, you told me it before in an other manner, the law goes quite against you, and therefore you must plead to the judge for favour.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O execrable bribery.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: Faith sir Judge, I pray you let me be the Gentleman's Counsellor, for I can say thus much in his defence, that the Usurers Clock is the swiftest Clock in all the Town, it is sir like a woman's tongue, it goes ever half an hour before the time: for when we were gone from him, other Clocks in the Town struck four.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.p: Hold thy prating fellow, and you young gentleman, this is my ward, look better an other time both to your bargains and to the payments, for I must give flat sentence against you: that for default of tendering the money between the hours, you have forfeited your recognisance, and he to have the land.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O inspeakable injustice.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.l: O monstrous, miserable, moth eaten Judge.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.l: Now you fellow, what have you to say for your matter?

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.l: Master Lawyer, I laid my wives gown to pawn for your fees, I pray you to this gear.

sp.speaker: Lawier.
sp.p: Alas poor man, thy matter is out of my head, and therefore I pray thee tell it thyself.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: I hold my Cap to a noble, that the Usurer hath given him some gold, and he chewing it in his mouth, hath got the toothache that he cannot speak.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.l: Well sirrah, I must be short, and therefore say on.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: Master. master Judge, I borrowed of this man thirty shillings for which, I left him in pawn my good Cow, the bargain was, he should have eighteen pence a week, and the Cows milk for usury: Now sir, as soon as I had gotten the money, I brought it him, and broke but a day, and for that he refused his money, and keeps my Cow sir.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.p: Why thou hast given sentence against thyself, for in breaking thy day, thou hast lost thy Cow.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.l: Master Lawyer, now for my ten shillings.

sp.speaker: Lawier.
sp.p: Faith poor man, thy Case is so bad, I shall but speak against thee.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: It were good then I should have my ten shillings again.

sp.speaker: Lawier.
sp.p: It is my fee fellow for coming , wouldst thou have me come for nothing?

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: Why then am I like to go home, not only with no Cow, but no gown: this gear goes hard.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.p: Well you have heard what favour I can show you, I must do justice, come Master. Mizaldo and you sir, go home with me to dinner.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.l: Why but Master. Judge, no cow, and Master. Lawyer no gown,
Then must I clean run out of the Town.
sp.p: How cheer you gentleman, you cry no lands too, the Judge hath made you a knight for a gentleman, hath dubbed you sir Iohn lackland.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O miserable time wherein gold is above God.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: Fear not man, I have yet a fetch to get thy lands and my cow again, for I have a son in the Court, that is either a King or a Kings fellow, and to him will I go and complain on the Judge and the Usurer both.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: And I will go with thee and entreat him for my Case.

sp.speaker: Poore.
sp.p: But how shall I go home to my wife, when I shall have nothing to say unto her, but no Cow. Alas sir, my wives faults will fall upon me.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Fear not, let us go, I will quiet her shalt see.

sp.speaker: Oseas.
sp.l: Fly Judges fly, corruption in your Court,
The Judge of truth, hath made your judgment short.
Look so to judge, that at the latter day,
Ye be not judged with those that wend astray.
Who passeth judgment for his private gain,
He well may judge, he is adjudged to pain.

body.stage: Enters the Clowne and all his crew drunke.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Farewell gentle Tapster, masters, as good ale as ever was tapped, look to your feet, for the ale is strong: well farewell gentle Tapster.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruffian.
sp.p: Why sirrah slave, by heavens maker, thinkest thou the wench loves thee best, because she laughed on thee, give me but such an other word, and I will throw the pot at thy head.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Spill no drink, spill no drink, the Ale is good, I will tell you what, ale is ale, and so I will commend me to you with hearty commendations: farewell gentle Tapster.
Why wherefore peasant scornest thou that the wench should love me, look but on her, and I will thrust my dagger in thy bosom

sp.speaker: 1. Ruffian.
sp.l: Well sirrah well, thou art as thou art, and so I will take thee.
Why what am I?
Why what thou wilt, a slave.
Then take that villain, and learn how to use me another time.
O I am slain.

sp.p: That is all one to me, I care not, now will I in to my wench and call for a fresh pot.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Nay but hear ye, take me with ye, for the ale is ale, cut a fresh toast Tapster, fill me a pot here is money, I am no beggar, I will follow thee as long as the ale lasts: a pestilence on the blocks for me, for I might have had a fall: well if we shall have no Ale I will sit me down, and so farewell gentle Tapster.

body.stage: Here he fals ouer the dead man.
Enters the King, Aluida, the King of Cilicia, and of Paphlagonia, with other attendant.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: What slaughtered wretch lies bleeding here his last?
So near the royal palace of the King,
Search out if anyone be biding nigh,
That can discourse the manner of his death,
Seat thee fair Aluida the fair of fairs,
Let not the otrict once offend thine eyes,

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: Here is one sits here asleep my Lord.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Wake him, and make enquiry of this thing.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Sirrah you, hearest thou fellow?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: If you will fill a fresh pot, here is a penny, or else farewell gentle Tapster.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: He is drunk my Lord.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: We will sport with him, that Aluida may laugh.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: Sirrah thou fellow, thou must come to the King.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: I will not do a stroke of work today, for the ale is good ale, and you can ask but a penny for a pot, no more by the statute.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: Villain, here is the King, thou must come to him.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: The King come to an Ale house? Tapster, fill me three pots, where is the King, is this he? Give me your hand sir, as good Ale as ever was tapped, you shall drink while your skin crack.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: But hearest thou fellow, who killed this man?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: I will tell you sir, if you did taste of the Ale, all Niniuie hath not such a cup of Ale, it flowers in the cup sir, by my troth I spent eleven pence beside three rases of ginger.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Answer me knave to my question, how came this man slain?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Slain, why ale is strong ale, it is huff-cap, I warrant you it will make a man well. Tapster ho, for the King a cup of ale and a fresh Toast, here is two rases more.

sp.speaker: Aluida.
sp.p: Why good fellow the King talks not of drink, he would have thee tell him how this man came dead.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Dead nay, I think I am alive yet, and will drink a full pot ere night, but hear ye, if ye be the wench that filled us drink, why so: do your office, and give us a fresh pot, or if you be the tapsters wife, why so, wash the glass clean.

sp.speaker: Aluida.
sp.l: He is so drunk my Lord, there is no talking with him.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Drunk, nay then wench I am not drunk, thou art a shitten quean, to call me drunk, I tell thee I am not drunk, I am a smith.

body.stage: Enters the Smith, the Clownes maister.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Sir, here comes one perhaps that can tell.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.l: God save you master.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Smith canst thou tell me how this man came dead?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: May it please your highness, my man here and a crew of them went to the ale house, and came out so drunk, that one of them killed another: and now sir, I am fain to leave my shop, and come to fetch him home.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.p: Some of you carry away the dead body, drunken men must have their fits, and sirrah Smith, hence with thy man.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.l: Sirrah you, rise come go with me.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: If we shall have a pot of Ale, let us have it, here is money: hold Tapster take my purse.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.l: Come then with me, the pot stands full in the house.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: I am for you, let us go, thou art an honest Tapster, we will drink six pots ere we part.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Beauteous, more bright than beauty in mine eyes,
Tell me fair sweating, wants thou anything ?
Contained within the threefold circle of the world,
That may make Aluida live full content.

sp.speaker: Aluida.
sp.l: Nothing my Lord, for all my thoughts are pleased,
When as mine eye surfeits with Rasnes sight.

body.stage: Enters the King of Paphlagonia, male-content.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Look how thy husband haunts our royal Courts,
How still his sight breeds melancholy storms,
O Aluida, I am passing passionate,
And vexed with wrath and anger to the death:
Mars when he held fair Venus on his knee,
And saw the limping Smith come from his forge,
Had not more deeper sorrows in his brow,
Than Rasni hath to see this Paphlagon.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: Content thee sweet, I will salve thy sorrow straight,
Rest but the ease of all thy thoughts on me,
And if I make not Rasni blithe again,
Then say that women's fancies have no shifts.

sp.speaker: Paphla.
sp.l: Shamest thou not Rasni though thou beest a King,
To shroud adultery in thy royal seat,
Art thou arch ruler of great Niniuie,
Who shouldest excel in virtue as in state,
And wrongest thy friend by keeping back his wife,
Have I not battled in thy troops full oft,
Against Egypt, Jewry and proud Babylon,
Spending my blood to purchase thy renown,
And is the guerdon of my chivalry,
Ended in this abusing of my wife?
Restore her me, or I will from thy Courts,
And make discourse of thy adulterous deeds.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.l: Why take her Paphlagon exclaim not man,
For I do prise mine honour more than love.
Fair Aluida go with thy husband home.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: How dare I go, shamed with so deep misdeed,
Revenge will broil within my husbands breast,
And when he hath me in the Court at home,
Then Aluida shall feel revenge for all.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: What sayst thou King of Paphlagon to this?
Thou hearest the doubt thy wife doth stand upon,
If she have done amiss it is my fault,
I prithee pardon and forget all.

sp.speaker: Paphla.
sp.l: If that I meant not Rasni to forgive,
And quite forget the follies that are past,
I would not vouchsafe her presence in my Courts,
But she shall be my Queen, my love, my life,
And Aluida unto her Paphlagon
And loved, and more beloved than before.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: What sayst thou Aluida to this?

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: That will he swear it to my Lord the king,
And in a full carouse of Greekish wine,
Drink down the malice of his deep revenge,
I will go home and love him new again .

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: What answers Paphlagon?

sp.speaker: Paphla.
sp.l: That what she hath requested I will do.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: Go Damoiselle fetch me that sweet wine,
That stands within thy Closet on the shelf,
Pour it into a standing bowl of gold,
But on thy life taste not before the King.
Make haste , why is great Rasni melancholy thus?
If promise be not kept, hate all for me.
Here is the wine my Lord, first make him swear.

sp.speaker: Paphla.
sp.l: By Niniuies great gods, and Niniuies great king.
My thoughts shall never be to wrong my wife,
And thereon here is a full carouse to her.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: And thereon Rasni here is a kiss for thee,
Now mayst thou freely fold thine Aluida.

sp.speaker: Paphla.
sp.l: O I am dead, obstructions of my breath,
The poison is of wondrous sharpe effect,
Cursed be all adulterous queens say I,
And cursing so, poor Paphlagon doth die.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: Now have I not salved the sorrows of my lord?
Have I not rid a rival of thy loves ,
What sayst thou Rasni to thy Paramour?

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: That for this deed I will deck my Aluida,
In Sendall and in costly Gossampine,
Bordered with Pearl and India Diamond,
I will cause great Eol perfume all his winds,
With richest myrrh and curious Amber greece,
Come lovely minion, paragon for fair,
Come follow me sweet goddess of mine eye,
And taste the pleasures Rasni will provide.

sp.speaker: Oseas.
sp.l: Where whoredom rains, there murther follows fast,
As falling leaves before the winter blast,
A wicked life, trained up in endless crime,
Hath no reward unto the latter time.
When Lechers shall be punished for their lust,
When Princes plagued, because they are unjust
Foresee in time, the warning bell doth toll,
Subdue the flesh, by prayer to save the soul.
London behold the cause of others wreck,
And set the sword of justice at thy back.
Defer not off, tomorrow is too late,
By night he comes perhaps to judge thy state.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: From forth the depth of my imprisoned soul,
Steal you my sighs, testify my pain,
Convey on wings of mine immortal tone,
My zealous prayers, unto the starry throne:
Ah merciful and just, thou dreadful God,
Where is thine arm to lay revengeful strokes
Upon the heads of our rebellious race?
Lo Israel once that flourished like the vine,
Is barren laid, the beautiful increase
Is wholly blent, and irreligious zeal
Encampeth there where virtue was enthroned,
Ah lass the while, the widow wants relief,
The fatherless is wronged by naked need,
Devotion sleeps in cinders of contempt,
Hypocrisy infects the holy Priest.
Aye me for this, woe me for these misdeeds,
Alone I walk to think upon the world,
And sigh to see thy Prophets so contemned:
Ah lass contemned by cursed Israel.
Yet Ionas rest content, it is Israel's sin
That causeth this, then muse no more thereon,
But pray amends, and mend thy own amiss.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Amithais son, I charge thee muse no more,
(I am) hath power to pardon and correct,
To thee pertains to do the Lords command.
Go girt thy loins, and haste thee quickly hence,
To Niniuie that mighty City wend,
And say this message from the Lord of hosts,
Preach unto them these tidings from thy God.
Behold thy wickedness hath tempted me,
And pierced through the nine-fold orbs of heaven:
Repent, or else thy judgment is at hand.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Prostrate I lie before the Lord of hosts,
With humble ears intending his behest,
Ah honoured be Iehouahs great command,
Then Ionas must to Niniuie repair,
Commanded as the Prophet of the Lord,
Great dangers on this journey to await,
But dangers none where heavens direct the course,
What should I deem, I see, yea sighing see,
How Israel sin, yet knows the way of truth,
And thereby grows the the by-word of the world,
How then should God in judgment be so strict?
Against those who never heard or knew his power,
To threaten utter ruin of them all:
Should I report this judgment of my God,
I should incite them more to follow sin,
And publish to the world my countries blame,
It may not be, my conscience tells me no.
Ah Ionas wilt thou prove rebellious then?
Consider ere thou fall, what error is,
My mind misgives, to Ioppa will I flee,
And for a while to Tharsus shape my course,
Until the Lord unfret his angry brows.

body.stage: Enter certaine merchants of Tharsus, a Maister, and some Sailers

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Come on brave merchants, now the wind doth serve,
And sweetly blows a gale at West, Southwest.
Our yards a cross, our anchors on the pike,
What shall we hence and take this merry gale?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sailors convey our budgets strait aboard,
And we will recompense your pains at last,
If once in safety we may Tharsus see,
Master. we will feast these merry mates and thee.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Meanwhile content yourselves with silly cates,
Our beds are boards, our feasts are full of mirth.
We use no pomp, we are the Lords of sea,
When Princes sweat in care, we swink of glee.
Orions shoulders and the pointers serve,
To be our Load stars in the lingering night,
The beauties of Arcturus we behold,
And though the Sailor is no book man held,
He knows more Art than ever book men read.

sp.speaker: Sailer.
sp.l: By heavens well said, in honour of our trade,
Let us see the proudest scholar stir his course
Or shift his tides as Silly sailors do.
Then will we yield them praise, else never none.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Well spoken fellow in thine own behalf,
But let us hence, wind tarries none you wot,
And tide and time let slip is hardly got.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: March to the Haven merchants, I follow you.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Now doth occasion further my desires,
I find companions fit to aid my flight,
Stay sir I pray, and hear a word or two.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Say on good friend, but briefly if you please,
My passengers by this time are aboard.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Whither pretend you to embark yourselves ?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: To Tharsus sir, and here in Ioppa haven
Our ship is pressed and ready to depart.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: May I have passage for my money then?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What not for money? pay ten silverlings,
You are a welcome guest if so you please.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Hold take thine hire, I follow thee my friend.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Where is your budget let me bare it sir.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: To one in peace, who sail as I do now,
Put trust in him, who succoureth every want.

sp.speaker: Ose.
sp.l: When Prophets new inspired, presume to force
And tie the power of heaven to their conceits,
When fear, promotion, pride, or simony,
Ambition, subtle craft, their thoughts disguise,
Woe to the flock whereas the shepherds fold,
For lo the Lord at unawares shall plague
The careless guide, because his flocks do stray:
The axe already to the tree is set,
Beware to tempt the Lord ye men of art.

body.stage: Enters Alcon, Thrasibulus, Samia, Clesiphon a lad.

sp.speaker: Clesi.
sp.l: Mother, some meat or else I die for want.

sp.speaker: Samia.
sp.l: Ah little boy how glad thy mother would
Supply thy wants, but naked need denies:
Thy fathers slender portion in this world,
By usury and false deceit is lost,
No charity within this City bides:
All for themselves, and none to help the poor.

sp.speaker: Chesi.
sp.l: Father, shall Clesiphon have no relief?

sp.speaker: Alcon.
sp.p: Faith my boy, I must be flat with thee, we must feed upon proverbs now. As necessity hath no law, a churls feast is better than none at all: for other remedies have we none, except thy brother Radagon help us.

sp.speaker: Samia.
sp.l: Is this thy slender care to help our child?
Hath nature armed thee to no more remorse?
Ah cruel man unkind and pitiless:
Come Clesiphon my boy, I will beg for thee.

sp.speaker: Clesi.
sp.l: O how my mothers mourning moveth me.

sp.speaker: Alcon.
sp.p: Nay you shall pay me interest for getting the boy (wife) before you carry him hence. Alas woman what can Alcon do more? I will pluck the belly out of my heart for thee sweet Samia be not so waspish.

sp.speaker: Samia.
sp.l: Ah silly man, I know thy want is great,
And foolishly I do crave where nothing is.
Haste Alcon haste, make haste unto our son,
Who since he is in favour of the King,
May help this hapless Gentleman and us.
For to regain our goods from tyrants hands.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Have patience Samia wait your weal from heaven,
The Gods have raised your son I hope for this,
To succour innocents in their distress

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Lo where he comes from the imperial Court,
Go, let us prostrate us before his feet.

sp.speaker: Alcon.
sp.p: Nay by my troth, I will never ask my son blessing, i trow, I taught him his lesson to know his father, what son Radagon, in faith boy how dost thee?

sp.speaker: Rada.
sp.l: Villain disturb me not, I cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Alcon.
sp.p: Tut son I will help you of that disease quickly, for I can hold thee, ask thy mother knave, what cunning I have to ease a woman, when a qualm of kindness come too near her stomach? Let me but clasp mine arms about her body and say my prayers in her bosom, and she shall be healed presently,

sp.speaker: Rada.
sp.l: Traitor unto my Princely Majesty,
How darest thou lay thy hands upon a king?

sp.speaker: Samia.
sp.l: No Traitor Radagon, but true is he,
What hath promotion bleared thus thine eye,
To scorn thy father when he visits thee?
Alas my son behold with ruthful eyes,
Thy parents robbed of all their worldly weal,
By subtle means of Usury and guile,
The Judges ears are deaf and shut up close,
All mercy sleeps, then be thou in these plunges
A patron to thy mother to her pains,
Behold thy brother almost dead for food,
O succour us, that first did succour thee.

sp.speaker: Rada.
sp.l: What succour me, falls callet hence avaunt?
Old dotard pack, move not my patience,
I know you not, Kings never look so low.

sp.speaker: Samia.
sp.l: You know us not. O Rada. you know,
That knowing us, you know your parents then,
Thou knowest this womb first brought thee forth to light,
I know these paps did foster thee my son.

sp.speaker: Alcon.
sp.p: And I know he hath had many a piece of bread and cheese at my hands, as proud as he is, that know I.

sp.speaker: Thracib.
sp.l: I wait no hope of succours in this place,
Where children hold their fathers in disgrace.

sp.speaker: Rada.
sp.l: Dare you enforce the furrows of revenge,
Within the brows of royal Radagon?
Villain avaunt, hence beggars with your brats,
Marshall, why whip ye you not these rogues away?
That thus disturb our royal Majesty.

sp.speaker: Clesiphon.
sp.l: Mother I see it is a wondrous thing,
From base estate for to become a King:
For why methink my brother in these fits,
Hath got a kingdom, and hath lost his wits.

sp.speaker: Rada.
sp.l: Yet more contempt before my royalty?
Slaves fetch out tortures worse than Titius plagues,
And tear their tongues from their blasphemous heads.

sp.speaker: Thrasi.
sp.l: I will get me gone, though woe begone with grief,
No hope remains, come Alcon let us wend.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: It were best you did, for fear you catch your bane.

sp.speaker: Samia.
sp.l: Nay Traitor, I will haunt thee to the death,
Ungracious son, untoward and perverse,
I will fill the heavens with echoes of thy pride,
And ring in every ear thy small regard,
That dost despise thy parents in their wants,
And breathing forth my soul before thy feet,
My curses still shall haunt thy hateful head,
And being dead, my ghost shall thee pursue.

body.stage: Enter Rasni King of Assiria, attended on by his sooth sayers and Kings.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: How now, what mean these outcries in our Court?
Where naught should sound, but harmonies of heaven,
What maketh Radagon so passionate?

sp.speaker: Samia.
sp.l: Justice, O King, justice against my son.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Thy son: what son?

sp.speaker: Samia.
sp.l: This cursed Radagon

sp.speaker: Rada.
sp.l: Dread Monarch, this is but a lunacy,
Which grief and want hath brought the woman to,
What doth this passion hold you every Moon?

sp.speaker: Samia.
sp.l: O politic in sin and wickedness,
Too impudent for to delude thy Prince.
O Rasni, this same womb brought him forth ,
This is his father, worn with care and age,
This is his brother, poor unhappy lad,
And I his mother, though contemned by him,
With tedious toil we got our little good,
And brought him up to school with mickle charge:
Lord how we joyed to see his towardness,
And to ourselves, we oft in silence said,
This youth when we are old may succour us.
But now preferred and lifted up by thee,
We quite destroyed by cursed usury,
He scorneth me, his father, and this child.

sp.speaker: Clesi.
sp.l: He plays the Serpent right, described in sopes tale,
That sought the fosters death, that lately gave him life.

sp.speaker: Alcon.
sp.p: Nay and please your majestyship, for proof he was my child, search the parish book: the Clarke will swear it, his godfathers and godmothers can witness it, it cost me forty pence in ale and cakes on the wives at his christening. Hence proud King, thou shalt never more have my blessing.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Say sooth in secret Radagon,
Is this thy father?

sp.speaker: Rada.
sp.l: Mighty King he is,
I blushing, tell it to your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.l: Why dost thou then contemn him and his friends?

sp.speaker: Rada.
sp.l: Because he is a base and abject swain,
My mother and her brat both beggarly,
Unmeet to be allied unto a King,
Should I that look on Rasnes countenance,
And march amidst his royal equipage,
Embase myself to speak to such as they?
It were impious so to impair the love
That mighty Rasni bears to Radagon.
I would your grace would quit them from your sight,
That dare presume to look on Jove's compare.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: I like thy pride, I praise thy policy,
Such should they be that wait upon my Court.
Let me alone to answer (Radagon.)
Villain seditious traitors as you be,
That scandalise the honour of a King,
Depart my Court, you stales of impudence,
Unless you would be parted from your limbs,
So base for to entitle father hood,
To Rasnes friend, to Rasnes favourite?

sp.speaker: Rada.
sp.l: Hence begging scold, hence caitiff clogged with years,
On pain of death revisit not the Court.
Was I conceived by such a scurvy trull,
Or brought to light by such a lump of dirt:
Go Losel trot it to the cart and spade,
Thou art unmeet to look upon a King,
Much less to be the father of a King.

sp.speaker: Alcon.
sp.p: You may see wife, what a goodly piece of work you have made, have I taught you Arsmetry as additiori multiplicarum, the rule of three, and all for the begetting of a boy, and to be banished for my labour. O pitiful hearing. Come Clesiphon follow me.

sp.speaker: Clesi.
sp.l: Brother beware, I oft have heard it told,
That sons who do their fathers scorn, shall beg when they be old.

sp.speaker: Radagon.
sp.l: Hence bastard boy for fear you taste the whip.

sp.speaker: Samia.
sp.l: O all you heavens, and you eternal powers,
That sway the sword of justice in your hands,
(If mothers curses of her sons contempt,
May fill the balance of your fury full)
Pour down the tempest of your direful plagues,
Upon the head of cursed Radagon.

body.stage: Vpon this praier she departeth, and a flame of fire appeareth from beneath, and Radagon is swallowed.

sp.speaker: Samia.
sp.l: So you are just, now triumph Samia

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: What exorcising charm, or hateful hag,
Hath ravished the pride of my delight?
What tortuous planets, or malevolent
Conspiring power, repining destiny
Hath made the concave of the earth unclose,
And shut in ruptures lovely Radagon?
If I be Lord commander of the clouds,
King of the earth, and Sovereign of the seas,
What daring Saturn from his fiery den,
Doth dart these furious flames amidst my Court?
I am not chief, there is more great than I,
What greater than The assirian Satrapos?
It may not be, and yet I fear there is,
That hath bereft me of my Radagon.

sp.speaker: Soothsaier.
sp.l: Monarch and Potentate of all our Provinces,
Muse not so much upon this accident,
Which is indeed nothing miraculous,
The hill of Scicely, dread Sovereign,
Sometime on sudden, doth evacuate,
Whole flakes of fire, and spews out from below
The smokey brands that Vulueus bellows drive,
Whether by winds enclosed in the earth,
Or fracture of the earth by rivers force,
Such chances as was this, are often seen,
Whole cities sunk, whole countries drowned quite,
Then muse not at the loss of Radagon.
But frolic with the dalliance of your love.
Let clothes of purple set with studs of gold,
Embellished with all the pride of earth,
Be spread for Aluida to sit upon.
Then thou like Mars courting the Queen of love,
Mayst drive away this melancholy fit.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: The proof is good, and philosophical,
And more, thy counsel plausible and sweet.
Come Lords, though Rasni wants his Radagon.
Earth will repay him many Radagons,
And Aluida with pleasant looks revive,
The heart that droops for want of Radagon.

sp.speaker: Oseas.
sp.l: When disobedience reigneth in the child,
And Princes ears by flattery be beguiled.
When laws do pass by favour, not by truth,
When falsehood swarmeth both in old and youth.
When gold is made a god to wrong the poor,
And charity exiled from rich men's door.
When men by wit, do labour to disprove,
The plagues for sin, sent down by God above.
Where great men's ears are stopped to good advice.
And apt to hear those tales that feed their vice.
Woe to the land, for from the East shall rise,
A lamb of peace, the scourge of vanities.
The judge of truth, the patron of the just,
Who soon will lay presumption in the dust.
And give the humble poor their hearts desire
And doom the worldlings to eternal fire.
Repent all you that hear, for fear of plagues,
O London, this and more doth swarm in thee,
Repent, repent, for why the Lord doth see.
With trembling pray, and mend what is amiss,
The sword of justice drawn already is.

body.stage: Eenter the Clowne and the Smiths wife.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Why but hear you mistress, you know a woman's eyes are like a pair of patterns, fit to save shoe-leather in summer, and to keep away the cold in winter, so you may like your husband with the one eye, because you are married, and me with the other, because I am your man. Alas, alas, think mistress what a thing love is, why it is like to an ostry faggot, that once set on fire, is as hardly quenched, as the bird Crocodile driven out of her nest.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why Adam cannot a woman wink but she must sleep, and can she not love, but she must cry it out at the Cross? know Adam I love thee as myself, now that we are together in secret.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Miss. these words of yours, are like a Fox tail, placed in a gentlewoman's Fan, which as it is light, so it giveth life. O these words are as sweet as a lily, whereupon offering a borachio of kisses to your unseemly personage, I entertain you upon further acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Alas my husband comes.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: Strike up the drum, and say no words but mum.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Sirrah you, and you housewife, well taken together, I have long suspected you, and now I am glad I have found you together.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Truly sir, and I am glad that I may do you any way pleasure, either in helping you or my mistress.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Boy here, and knave you shall know it straight, I will have you both before the Magistrate, and there have you surely punished.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: Why then master you are jealous?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Jealous knave, how can I be but jealous, to see you ever so familiar together? thou art not only content to drink away my goods but to abuse my wife.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: Two good qualities, drunkenness and lechery, but master are you jealous?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Aye knave, and thou shalt know it ere I pass, for I will beswing thee while this rope will hold.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: My good husband abuse him not for he never proffered you any wrong,

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.l: Nay whore, thy part shall not be behind.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Why suppose master I have offended you, it is lawful for the master to beat the servant for all offences?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.l: Aye marry is it knave.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Then master will I prove by logic, that seeing all sins are to receive correction, the master is to be corrected of the man, and sir I pray you, what greater sin is, then jealousy? it is like a mad dog that for anger bites himself. Therefore that I may do my duty to you good master, and to make a white son of you, I will beswing jealousy out of you, as you shall love me the better while you live.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.l: What beat thy master knave?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: What beat thy man knave? and I master, and double beat you, because you are a man of credit, and therefore have at you, the fairest of forty pence.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.l: Alas wife, help, help, my man kills me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nay, even as you have baked, so brew, jealousy must be driven out by extremities.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: and that will I do, mistress.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Hold thy hand Adam, and not only I forgive and forget all, but I will give thee a good Farm to live on.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Be gone Peasant, out of the compass of my further wrath, for I am a corrector of vice, and at night I will bring home my mistress.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.l: Even when you please good Adam

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: When I please, mark thy words, it is a lease parole, to have and to hold, thou shalt be mine forever, and so let us go to the ale house.

sp.speaker: Oseas.
sp.l: Where servants against masters do rebel,
The Common-weal may be accounted hell.
For if the feet the head shall hold in scorn,
The Cities state will fall and be forlorn.
This error London, waiteth on thy state,
Servants amend, and masters leave to hate.
Let love abound, and virtue reign in all,
So God will hold his hand that threateneth thrall.

body.stage: Enter the Marchants of Tharsus, the M. of the ship, some Sailers, wet from sea, with them the Gouernour of Ioppa.

sp.speaker: Gouer. Iop.
sp.l: What strange encounters met you on the sea?
That thus your Bark is battered by the floods,
And you return thus sea wracked as I see.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Most mighty governor the chance is strange,
The tidings full of wonder and amaze,
Which better than we, our Master. can report.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: Master. discourse us all the accident.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The fair Triones with their glimmering light
Smiled at the foot of clear Roots a rain,
And in the wrath distinguishing the hours,
The Lodestar of our course dispersed his clear,
When to the seas with blitheful western blasts,
We sailed amain, and let the bowling fly?
Scarce had we gone ten leagues from sight of land,
But lo an host of black and sable clouds,
Gan to eclipse Lucinas silver face,
And with a hurling noise from forth the South,
A gust of wind did raise the billows up,
Then scantled we our sails with speedy hands,
And took our drabblers from our bonnets straight,
And severed our bonnets from our courses,
Our topsails up, we truss our sprit-sails in,
But vainly strive they that resist the heavens.
For lo the waves incense them more and more,
Mounting with hideous roarings from the depth,
Our Bark is battered by encountering storms,
And well-nigh stemmed by breaking of the floods,
The steers-man pale, and careful holds his helm,
Wherein the trust of life and safety lay,
Till all at once a (mortal tale to tell)
Our sails were split by Bisas bitter blast,
Our rudder broke and we bereft of hope,
There might you see with pale and ghastly looks,
The dead in thought, and doleful merchants lifts,
Their eyes and hands unto their Countries Gods,
The goods we cast in bowels of the sea,
A sacrifice to suage proud Neptune's ire,
Only alone a man of Israel
A passenger, did under hatches lie,
And slept secure, when we for succour prayed:
Him I awoke, and said: why slumberest thou?
Arise and pray, and call upon thy God,
He will perhaps in pity look on us.
Then cast we lots to know by whose amiss
Our mischief come, according to the guise,
And lo the lot did unto Ionas fall,
The Israelite of whom I told you last,
Then question we his Country and his name,
Who answered us, I am and Nebrue borne
Who fear the Lord of Heaven, who made the sea,
And fled from him for which we all are plagued,
So to assuage the fury of my God,
Take me and cast my carcass in the sea,
Then shall this stormy wind and billow cease.
The heavens they know, the Hebrews God can tell,
How loath we were to execute his will:
But when no Oars nor labour might suffice,
We heaved the hapless Ionas over board.
So ceased the storm, and calmed all the sea,
And we by strength of oars recovered shore.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: A wondrous chance of mighty consequence.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Ah honoured be the god that wrought the same,
For we have vowed, that saw his wondrous works,
To cast away profaned Paganism,
And count the Hebrews God the only God.
To him this offering of the purest gold,
This myrrh and Cassia freely I do yield.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: And on his alters perfume these Turkey clothes,
This gossampine and gold I will sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Sailer.
sp.l: To him my heart and thoughts I will addict,
Then suffer us most mighty Governor,
Within your Temples to do sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: You men of Tharsus follow me,
Who sacrifice unto your God of heaven,
And welcome friends to Ioppais Governor.

sp.speaker: Oseas.
sp.l: If warned once, the Ethnicks thus repent,
And at the first their error do lament:
What senseless beasts devoured in their sin,
Are they whom long persuasions cannot win.
Beware ye western Cities, where the word
Is daily preached both at church and board:
Where majesty the Gospel doth maintain,
Where Preachers for your good, themselves do pain.
To dally long, and still protract the time,
The Lord is just, and you but dust and slime:
Presume not far, delay not to amend,
Who suffereth long, will punish in the end.
Cast thy account of London in this case,
Then judge what cause thou hast, to call for grace.

body.stage: Ionas the Prophet cast out of the Whales belly vppon the Stage.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Lord of the light, thou maker of the word,
Behold thy hands of mercy rears me up,
Lo from the hideous bowels of this fish,
Thou hast returned me to the wished air,
Lo here apparent witness of thy power,
The proud Leviathan that scours the seas,
And from his nostrils shores out stormy floods,
Whose back resists the tempest of the wind,
Whose presence makes the scaly troops to shake,
With humble stress of his broad opened chaps,
Hath lent me harbour in the raging floods.
Thus though my sin hath drawn me down to death,
Thy mercy hath restored me to life.
Bow ye my knees, and you my bashful eyes,
Weep so for grief, as you to water would:
In trouble Lord, I called unto thee,
Out of the belly of the deepest hell,
I cried, and thou didst hear my voice O God:
It is thou hadst cast me down into the deep,
The seas and floods did compass me about,
I thought I had been cast from out thy sight,
The weeds were wrapped about thy wretched head,
I went unto the bottom of the hills,
But thou O Lord my God hast brought me up.
On thee I thought when as my soul did faint,
My prayers did praise before thy mercy seat.
Then will I pay my vows unto the Lord,
For why, salvation cometh from his throne.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Ionas arise, get thee to Niniuie,
And preach to them the preachings that I bad:
Haste thee to see the will of heaven performed.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Iehouah I am Priest to do thy will.
What coast is this, and where am I arrived?
Behold sweet Licas streaming in his bounds,
Bearing the walls of haughty Niniuie,
Whereas three hundred towns do tempt the heaven.
Fair are the walls pride of Assiria,
But lo thy sins have pierced through the clouds.
Here will I enter boldly, since I know
My God commands, whose power no power resists.

sp.speaker: Oseas.
sp.l: You Prophets learn by Ionas how to live
Repent your sins, whilst he doth warning give.
Who knows his masters will and doth it not,
Shall suffer many stripes full well I wot.

body.stage: Enter Aluida in rich attire, with the King of Cilicia, her Ladies.

sp.speaker: Aluida.
sp.l: Ladies go sit you down amidst this bower,
And let the Eunuchs play you all asleep:
Put garlands made of Roses on your heads,
And play the wantons whilst I talk a while.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Though beautiful of all the world we will.

sp.speaker: Aluid.
sp.l: King of Cilicias kind and courteous,
Like to thyself, because a lovely King,
Come lay thee down upon thy mistress knee,
And I will sing and talk of love to thee.

sp.speaker: King Cili.
sp.l: Most gracious Paragon of excellence,
It fits not such an abject Prince as I,
To talk with Rasnes Paramour and love .

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: To talk sweet friend? who would not talk with thee?
O be not coy, art thou not only fair?
Come twine thine arms about this snow white neck,
A love nest for the great Assirian King,
Blushing I tell thee fair Cilician Prince,
None but thyself can merit such a grace.

sp.speaker: K. Ci.
sp.l: Madam, I hope you mean not for to mock me:

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: No king, fair king, my meaning is to yoke thee.
Hear me but sing of love, then by my sighs,
My tears, my glancing looks, my changed cheer,
Thou shalt perceive how I do hold thee dear.

sp.speaker: K. Ci.
sp.l: Sing Madam if you please, but love in jest,

sp.speaker: Aluid.
sp.l: Nay, I will love, and sigh at every rest.
Beauty alas, where wast thou borne?
Thus to hold thyself in scorn:
When as beauty kissed to woo thee,
Thou by Beauty dost undo me.
Heigh ho, despise me not.
I and thou in sooth are one,
Fairer thou, I fairer none:
Wanton thou, and wilt thou wanton
Yield a cruel heart to plant on?
Do me right and do me reason,
Cruelty is cursed treason.
Heigh ho I love, heigh ho I love,
High ho, and yet he eyes me not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Madam your song is passing passionate.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: And wilt thou not then pity my estate?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ask love of them, who pity may impart.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: I ask of thee sweet, thou hast stole my heart.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your love is fixed on a greater King.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: Tut women's love, it is a fickle thing.
I love my Rasni for my dignity.
I love Cilician King for his sweet eye.
I love my Rasni since he rules the world.
But more I love this kingly little world.
How sweet he looks? O were I Cithias Peer,
And thou Endimion, I should hold thee dear:
Thus should mine arms be spread about thy neck.
Thus would I kiss my love at every beck.
Thus would I sigh to see thee sweetly sleep,
And If thou wakest not soon, thus would I weep.
And thus, and thus, and thus: thus much I love thee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: For all these vows, beshrew me if I prove you:
My faith unto my King shall not be falsed.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: Good Lord how men are coy when they are craved?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Madam, behold our King approacheth nigh.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: Thou art Endimion, then no more, heigh ho for him I die.

body.stage: Faints. Point at the King of Cilicia.
Enter Rasni, with his Kings and Lords.

sp.l: What ails the centre of my happiness,
Whereon depends the heaven of my delight?
Thine eyes the motors to command my world,
Thy hands the axier to maintain my world.
Thy smiles, the prime and spring tide of my world.
Thy frowns, the winter to afflict the world.
Thou Queen of me, I King of all the world.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: Ah feeble eyes lift up and look on him.

body.stage: She riseth as out of a trance.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: Is Rasni here? then droop no more poor heart,
O how I fainted when I wanted thee?
How fain am I, now I may look on thee?
How glorious is my Rasni? how divine?
Eunuchs play hymns, to praise his deity:
He is my Jove, and I his Juno am.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Sun-bright, as is the eye of summers day,
When as he suits Spenori all in gold,
To woo his Leda in a swan-like shape.
Seemly as Galbocia for thy white:
Rose-coloured, lily, lovely, wanton, kind,
Be thou the labyrinth to tangle love,
Whilst I command the crown from Venus crest:
And pull Onoris girdle from his loins,
Enchased with Carbuncles, and Diamonds,
To beautify fair Aluida my love .
Play Eunuchs, sing in honour of her name,
Yet look not slaves upon her wooing eyen,
For she is fair Lucina to your King,
But fierce Medusa to your baser eye.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: What if I slept, where should my pillow be?

sp.speaker: Rasni.
