sp.l: Within my bosom Nymph, not on my knee,
Sleep like the smiling purity of heaven,
When mildest wind is loath to blend the peace,
Meanwhile thy blame shall from thy breath arise,
And while these closures of thy lamps be shut,
My soul may have his peace from fancies war.
This is my Morane and I her Cephalus.
Wake not too soon sweet Nymph, my love is won:
Catnies, why stay your strains, why tempt you me?

body.stage: Enter the Priest of the sun, with the miters on their heads, carrying fire in their hands.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: All hail unto The Assirian deity.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.l: Priests why presume you to disturb my peace?

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: Rasni, the destinies disturb thy peace.
Behold amidst the addittes of our Gods,
Our mighty Gods the patrons of our war.
The ghost of dead men howling walk about,
Crying Ve, Ve, woe to this City woe.
The statutes of our Gods are thrown down,
And streams of blood our altars do distain.

sp.speaker: Aluida.
sp.l: Alas my Lord, what tidings do I hear?
Shall I be slain?

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Who tempteth Aluida?
Go break me up the brazen walls of dreams,
And bind me cursed Morpheus in a chain,
And fetter all the fancies of the night,
Because they do disturb my Aluida.

body.stage: A hand from out a cloud, threatneth a burning sword.

sp.speaker: K Cili.
sp.l: Behold dread Prince, a burning sword from heaven,
Which by a threatening arm is brandished.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: What am I threatened then amidst my throne?
Sages? you Magi speak: what meaneth this?

sp.speaker: Sages.
sp.l: These are but clammy exhalations,
Or retrograde conjunctions of the stars,
Or oppositions of the greater lights.
Or radiatrous finding matter fit,
That in the starry Sphere kindled be,
Matters betokening dangers to thy foes,
But peace and honour to my Lord the King.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Then frolic Viceroys, kings and potentates,
Drive all vain fancies from your feeble minds.
Priests go and pray, whilst I prepare my feast,
Where Aluida and I, in pearl and gold,
Will quaff unto our Nobles, richest wine,
In spite of fortune, fate, or destiny.

sp.speaker: Oseas.
sp.l: Woe to the trains of women's foolish lust,
In wedlock rights that yield but little trust.
That vow to one, yet common be to all,
Take warning wantons, pride will have a fall.
Woe to the land, where warnings profit naught,
Who say that nature, Gods decrees hath wrought.
Who build on fate, and leave the corner stone,
The God of Gods, sweet Christ the only one.
If such escapes London reign in thee:
Repent, for why each sin shall punished be.
Repent, amend, repent the hour is nigh,
Defer not time, who knows when he shall die?

body.stage: Enters one clad in diuels attire alone.

sp.p: Longer lives a merry man than a sad, and because I mean to make myself pleasant this night, I have put myself into this attire, to make a Clown afraid, that passeth this way: for of late there have appeared many strange apparitions, to the great fear and terror of the Citizens. O here my young master comes.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Fear not mistress, I will bring you safe home, if my master frown, then will I stamp and stare, and if all be not well then, why then tomorrow morn put out mine eyes clean with forty pound.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O but Adam, I am afraid to walk so late because of the spirits that appear in the City.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: What are you afraid of spirits, armed as I am, with Ale, and Nutmegs, turn me loose to all the devils in hell.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Alas Adam, Adam the devil, the devil.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: The devil mistress, fly you for your safeguard, let me alone, the devil and I will deal well enough, if he have any honesty at all in him, I will either win him with a smooth tale, or else with a toast and a cup of Ale.

sp.speaker: Diuell.
sp.l: O, o, o, o, fain would I be,
If that my kingdom fulfilled I might see.
O, o, o, o.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Surely this is a merry devil, and I believe he is one of Lucifers Minstrels, hath a sweet voice, now surely, surely, he may sing to a pair of tongues and a Bagpipe.

sp.speaker: Diuell.
sp.l: O thou art he that I seek for.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: Spiritus santus, away from me satan, I have nothing to do with thee.

sp.speaker: Diuell.
sp.l: O villain thou art mine.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Nominus patrus, I bless me from thee, and I conjure thee to tell me who thou art?

sp.speaker: Diuell.
sp.p: I am the spirit of the dead man that was slain in thy company when we were drunk together at the Ale.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: By my troth sir, I cry you mercy, your face is so changed, that I had quite forgotten you, well master devil we have tossed over many a pot of ale together.

sp.speaker: Diuell.
sp.l: And therefore must thou go with me to hell.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: I have a policy to shift him, for I know he comes out of a hot place, and I know myself , the Smith and the devil hath a dry tooth in his head, therefore will I leave him asleep, and run my way.

sp.speaker: Diuell.
sp.l: Come art thou ready.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Faith sir my old friend, and now goodman devil, you know, you and I have been tossing many a good cup of ale, your nose is grown very rich, what say you, will you take a pot of ale now at my hands, hell is like a Smiths forge full of water, and yet ever a thrust.

sp.speaker: Diuell.
sp.p: No Ale villain, spirits cannot drink, come get up on my back, that I may carry thee.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: You know I am a Smith sir, let me look whither you be well shod or no, for if you want a shoe, a remove, or the clinching of a nail, I am at your command.

sp.speaker: Diuell.
sp.l: Thou hast never a shoe fit for me.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Why sir, we shoe horned beasts as well as you, O Good Lord, let me sit down and laugh, hath never a cloven foot, a devil quoth he, I will use spritus santus nor nominus patrus no more to him, I warrant you, I will do more good upon him with my cudgel, now will I sit me down and become Justice of peace to the devil.

sp.speaker: Diuell.
sp.l: Come art thou ready?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: I am ready. And with this cudgel I will conjure thee.

sp.speaker: Diuell.
sp.l: O hold thy hand, thou killest me, thou killest me.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Then may I count self I think a tall man, that am able to kill a devil. Now who dare deal with me in the parish, or what wench in Niniuie will not love me, when they say, there goes he that beat the devil.

sp.speaker: Thrasi.
sp.l: Loathed is the life that now enforced I lead,
But since necessity will have it so,
(Necessity it doth command the Gods)
Through every coast and corner now I pry.
To pilfer what I can to buy me meat.
Here have I got a cloak not over old,
Which will afford some little sustenance,
Now will I to the broking Usurer,
To make exchange of ware for ready coin.

sp.speaker: Alcon.
sp.p: Wife bid the trumpets sound a prize, a prize, mark the posy, I cut this from a new married wife, by the help of a horn thumb and a knife, six shillings four pence.

sp.speaker: Smia.
sp.p: The better luck ours, but what have we here, cast apparel? Come away man, the Usurer is near, this is dead ware, let it not bide on our hands.

sp.speaker: Thrasi.
sp.l: Here are my partners in my poverty,
Enforced to seek their fortunes as I do.
Alas that few men should possess the wealth,
And many souls be forced to beg or steal.
Alcon well met.

sp.speaker: Alcon.
sp.l: Fellow beggar whither now?

sp.speaker: Thrasi.
sp.l: To the Usurer to get gold on commodity.

sp.speaker: Alcon.
sp.p: And I to the same place to get a vent for my villainy, see where the old crust comes, let us salute him. God speed sir, may a man abuse your patience upon a pawn?

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.l: Friend let me see it.

sp.speaker: Alcon.
sp.p: Ecce signum, a fair doublet and hose, new bought out of the pilferers shop, a handsome cloak.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.l: How were they gotten?

sp.speaker: Thrasi.
sp.p: How catch the fishermen fish? Master. take them as you think them worth, we leave all to your conscience.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: Honest men, toward men, good men, my friends, like to prove good members, use me, command me, I will maintain your credits, there is money, now spend not your time in idleness, bring me commodity, I have crowns for you, there is two shillings for thee, and six shillings for thee.

sp.speaker: Alcon.
sp.p: A bargain, now Samia have at it for a new smock, come let us to the spring of the best liquor, whilst this lasts, trillill.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.p: Good fellows, proper fellows, my companions, farewell, I have a pot for you.

sp.speaker: Samia.
sp.l: If he could spare it.
Repent ye men of Niniuie repent,
The day of judgment comes.
When greedy hearts shall glutted be with fire.
When as corruptions veiled, shall be unmasked.
When briberies shall be repaid with bane.
When whoredoms shall be recompensed in hell.
When riot shall with rigour be rewarded.
When as neglect of truth, contempt of God,
Disdain of poor men, fatherless and sick
Shall be rewarded with a bitter plague.
Repent ye men of Niniuie repent.
The Lord hath spoke, and I do cry it out.
There are as yet, but forty days remaining,
And then shall Niniuie be overthrown.
Repent ye men of Niniuie repent.
There are as yet but forty days remaining,
And then shall Niniuie be overthrown.

sp.speaker: Vsur.
sp.l: Confused in thought, o whither shall I wend?

sp.speaker: Thrasi.
sp.l: My conscience cries that I have done amiss.
sp.p: O God of heaven, against thee have I offended.

sp.speaker: Samia.
sp.l: Ashamed of my misdeeds, where shall I hide me?

sp.speaker: Clesi.
sp.l: Father methinks this word repent is good,
He that punish disobedience.
Doth hold a scourge for every privy fault.

sp.speaker: Oseas.
sp.l: Look London look, with inward eyes behold,
What lessons the events do here unfold.
Sin grown to pride, to misery is thrall,
The warning bell is rung, beware to fall.
Ye worldly men whom wealth doth lift on hie,
Beware and fear, for worldly men must die.
The time shall come, where least respect remains,
The sword shall light upon the wisest brains.
The head that deems to overtop the sky,
Shall perish in his human policy.
Lo I have said, when I have said the truth,
When will is law, when folly guideth youth.
When show of zeal is pranked in robes of zeal,
When Ministers poll the pride of common-weal?
When Law is made a labyrinth of strife,
When honour yields him friend to wicked life.
When Princes hear by others ears their folly,
When Usury is most accounted holy.
If these should hap, as would to God they might not,
The plague is near, I speak although I write not.

sp.speaker: Angell.
sp.l: Oseas.

sp.speaker: Oseas.
sp.l: Lord.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Now hath thine eyes perused these heinous sins,
Hateful unto the mighty Lord of hosts,
The time is come, their sins are waxen ripe,
And though the Lord forewarns, yet they repent not:
Custom of sin hath hardened all their hearts,
Now comes revenge armed with mighty plagues,
To punish all that live in Niniuie
For God is just, as he is merciful,
And doubtless plagues all such as scorn repent,
Thou shalt not see the desolation
That falls unto these cursed Niniuites
But shalt return to great Jerusalem,
And preach unto the people of thy God,
What mighty plagues are incident to sin,
Unless repentance mitigate his ire:
Wrapped in the spirit as thou wert hither brought,
I will seat thee in Iudeas provinces,
Fear not Oseas then to preach the word.

sp.speaker: Oseas.
sp.l: The will of the Lord be done.

body.stage: Enters Rasni with his Viceroyes, Aluida and Ladies, to a banquet.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: So Viceroys you have pleased me passing well,
These curious cates are gracious in mine eye.
But these Borachious of the richest wine,
Make me to think how blithesome we will be.
Seat thee fair Juno in the royal throne,
And I will serve thee to see thy face,
That feeding on the beauty of thy looks,
My stomach and mine eyes may both be filled.
Come Lordings seat you, fellow mates at feast,
And frolic wags, this is a day of glee,
This banquet is for brightsome Aluida
I will have them skinked my standing bowls of wine,
And no man drink, but quaff a full carouse,
Unto the health of beauteous Aluida.
For who so riseth from this feast not drunk,
As I am Rasni, Niniuies great King,
Shall die the death as traitor to myself,
For that he scorns the health of Aluida.

sp.speaker: K. Cili.
sp.l: That will I never do my Lord.
Therefore with favour, fortune to your grace,
Carouse unto the health of Aluida.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Gramercy Lording, here I take thy pledge.
And Creete to thee a bowl of Greekish wine,
Here to the health of Aluida.

sp.speaker: Creete.
sp.l: Let come my Lord, Jack scincker fill it full,
I pledge unto the health of heavenly Aluida.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Vassals attendant on our royal feasts,
Drink you I say unto my lovers health,
Let none that is in Rasnes royal Court,
Go this night safe and sober to his bed.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: This way he is, and here will I speak with him.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Fellow, whither pressest thou?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: I press nobody sir, I am going to speak with a friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Why slave, here is none but the king and his Viceroys.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: The King, marry sir he is the man I would speak withal.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: why callest him a friend of thine?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Aye marry do I sir, for if he be not my friend, I will make him my friend, ere he and I pass.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Away vassal be gone, thou speak unto the king.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: Aye marry will I sir, and if he were a King of velvet, I will talk to him.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: What is the matter there, what noise is that?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: A boon my Liege, a boon my Liege.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: What is it that great Rasni will not grant
This day, unto the meanest of his land?
In honour of his beauteous Aluida?
Come hither swain, what is it that thou cravest?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Faith sir nothing, but to speak a few sentences to your worship.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Say, what is it?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I am sure sir you have heard of the spirits that walk in the City here.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Aye , what of that?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Truly sir, I have an oration to tell you of one of them, and this it is.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: Why goest not forward with thy tale?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Faith mistress, I feel an imperfection in my voice, a disease that often troubles me, but alas, easily mended, a cup of Ale, or a cup of Wine, will serve the turn.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: Fill him a bowl, and let him want no drink.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: O what a precious word was that, and let him want no drink. Well sir, now I will tell you forth my tale. Sir as I was coming alongst the port rival of Niniuie, there appeared to me a great devil, and as hard favoured a devil as ever I saw: nay sir, he was a cuckoldly devil, for he had horns on his head. This devil, mark you now, presseth upon me, and sir indeed, I charged him with my pike staff: but when that would not serve, I came upon him with sprytus santus, why it had been able to have put Lucifer out of his wits, when I saw my charm would not serve, I was in such a perplexity, that six penny worth of Juniper would not have made the place sweet again.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: Why fellow wert thou so afraid?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: O mistress, had you been there and seen, his very sight had made you shift a clean smock, I promise you though I were a man, and counted a tall fellow, yet my Laundress called me slovenly knave the next day.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: A pleasant slave, forward sirrah, on with thy tale.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Faith sir, but I remember a word that my mistress your bedfellow spoke.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: What was that fellow?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: O sir, a word of comfort, a precious word: and let him want no drink.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Her word is law: and thou shalt want no drink.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Then sir this devil came upon me , and would not be persuaded, but he would needs carry me to hell, I proffered him a cup of Ale, thinking because he came from so hot a place, that he was thirsty, but the devil was not dry, and therefore the more sorry was I, well, there was no remedy, but I must with him to hell, and at last I cast mine eye aside, if you knew what I spied, you would laugh, sir I looked from top to toe, and he had no cloven feet. Then I ruffled up my hair, and set my cap on the one side, and sir grew to be a Justice of peace to the devil. At last in a great fume, as I am very choleric, and sometime so hot in my fustian fumes, that no man can abide within twenty yards of me, I start up, and so bombasted the devil, that sir he cried out, and ran away.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: This pleasant knave hath made me laugh my fill.
Rasni, now Aluida begins her quaff,
And drinks a full carouse unto her King.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: I pledge my love, as hearty as great Jove
Drunk, when his Juno heaved a bowl to him.
Frolic my Lord, let all the standards walk.
Ply it till every man hath taken his load.
How now sirrah, what cheer: we have no words of you?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Truly sir, I was in a brown study about my mistress.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: About me, for what?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Truly mistress, to think what a golden sentence you did speak: all the philosophers in the world could not have said more: what come let him want no drink. O wise speech.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: Villains, why skink you not unto this fellow?
He makes me blithe and merry in my thoughts.
Heard you not that the King hath given command,
That all be drunk this day within his Court,
In quaffing to the health of Aluida?

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Repent, repent, ye men of Niniuie repent.
The Lord hath spoken, and I do cry it out,
There are as yet but forty days remaining,
And then shall Niniuie be overthrown.
Repent ye men of Niniuie, repent.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: What fellow is this, that thus disturbs our feasts,
With outcries and alarums to repent?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: O sir, it is one goodman Ionas that is come from Iericho, and surely I think he hath seen some spirit by the way, and is fallen out of his wits, for he never leaves crying night nor day, my master heard him, and he shut up his shop, gave me my Indenture, and he and his wife do nothing but fast and pray.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Repent ye men of Niniuie, repent.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Come hither fellow, what art, and from whence comest thou?

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Rasni, I am a Prophet of the Lord,
Sent hither by the mighty God of hosts,
To cry destruction to the Niniuites,
O Niniuie, thou harlot of the world,
I raise thy neighbours round about thy bounds,
To come and see thy filthiness and sin.
Thus saith the Lord, the mighty God of host,
Your King loves chambering and wantonness,
Whoredom and murther do distain his Court,
He favoureth covetous and drunken men.
Behold therefore all like a strumpet foul,
Thou shalt be judged and punished for thy crime:
The foe shall pierce the gates with iron ramps,
The fire shall quite consume thee from above.
The houses shall be burnt, the Infants slain.
And women shall behold their husbands die.
Thine eldest Sister is Lamana.
And Sodome on thy right hand seated is.
Repent ye men of Niniuie, repent.
The Lord hath spoke, and I do cry it out.
There are as yet but forty days remaining,
And then shall Niniuie be overthrown.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Stay Prophet, stay.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Disturb not him that sent me,
Let me perform the message of the Lord.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: My soul is buried in the hell of thoughts.
Ah Aluida, I look on thee with shame.
My Lords on sudden fix their eyes on ground,
As if dismayed to look upon the heavens.
Hence Magi, who have flattered me in sin.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Horror of mind, disturbance of my soul,
Makes me aghast, for Niniuies mishap.
Lords see proclaimed, yea see it straight proclaimed,
That man and beast, the woman and her child,
For forty days in sack and ashes fast,
Perhaps the Lord will yield and pity us.
Bear hence these wretched blandishments of sin,
And bring me sackcloth to attire your King.
Away with pomp, my soul is full of woe:
In pity look on Niniuie, O God.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: Assailed with shame, with horror overborne,
To sorrows sold, all guilty of our sin.
Come Ladies come, let us prepare to pray,
Alas, how dare we look on heavenly light,
That have despised the maker of the same?
How may we hope for mercy from above,
That still despise the warnings from above?
Woes me, my conscience is a heavy foe.
O patron of the poor oppressed with sin,
Look, look on me, that now for pity crave,
Assailed with shame, with horror overborne,
To sorrow sold, all guilty of our sin.
Come Ladies come, let us prepare to pray.

body.stage: Enter the Vsurer, solus with a halter in one hand, a dagger in the other.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.l: Groaning in conscience, burdened with my crimes,
The hell of sorrow haunts me up and down .
Tread where I list, methinks the bleeding ghosts
Of those whom my corruption brought to noughts,
Do serve for stumbling blocks before my steppes.
The fatherless and widow wronged by me.
The poor oppressed by my usury,
Methinks I see their hands reared up to heaven,
To cry for vengeance of my covetousness.
Where so I walk, I will sigh and shun my way.
Thus am I made a monster of the world,
Hell gapes for me, heaven will not hold my soul.
You mountains shroud me from the God of truth.
Methinks I see him sit to judge the earth.
See how he blots me out of the book of life.
O burthen more than Atna that I bear.
Cover me hills, and shroud me from the Lord.
Swallow me Licas, shield me from the Lord.
In life no peace: each murmuring that I hear ,
Methinks the sentence of damnation sounds,
Die reprobate, and hie thee hence to hell.

body.stage: The euill angell tempteth him, offering the knife and rope.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.l: What fiend is this that tempts me to the death?
What is my death the harbour of my rest?
Then let me die: what second charge is this?
Methink , I hear a voice amidst mine ears,
That bids me stay: and tells me that the Lord
As merciful to those that do repent.
May I repent? o thou my doubtful soul?
Thou mayst repent, the judge is merciful.
Hence tools of wrath, stales of temptation,
For I will pray and sigh unto the Lord.
In sackcloth will I sigh, and fasting pray:
O Lord in rigour look not on my sins.

body.stage: He sits him down in sack cloathes, his hands and eyes reared to heauen.
Enters Aluida with her Ladies, with dispiersed lookes.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: Come mournful dames lay off your broidered locks,
And on your shoulders spread dispersed hairs,
Let voice of music cease, where sorrow dwells.
Clothed in sackcloths, sigh your sins with me.
Bemoan your pride, bewail your lawless lusts,
With fasting mortify your pampered loins:
O think upon the horror of your sins.
Think, think, with me, the burthen of your blames,
Woe to thy pomp, fall, beauty, fading flower,
Blasted by age, by sickness, and by death.
Woe to our painted cheeks, our curious oils,
Our rich array, that fostered us in sin.
Woe to our idle thoughts that wound our souls.
O would to God, all nations might receive,
A good example by our grievous fall.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.l: You that are planted there where pleasure dwells,
And thinks your pomp as great as Niniuies,
May fall for sin as Niniuie doth now.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: Mourn, mourn, let moan be all your melody,
And pray with me, and I will pray for all.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: O Lord of heaven forgive us our misdeeds.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.l: O Lord of heaven forgive us our misdeeds.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.l: O Lord of light forgive me my misdeeds.

body.stage: Enters Rasni, the kings of Assiria, with his nobles in sackcloath.

sp.speaker: K. Cilicia.
sp.l: Be not so overcome with grief O king,
Lest you endanger life by sorrowing so.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: King of Cilicia, should I cease my grief,
Where as my swarming sins afflict my soul?
Vain man know, this my burthen greater is,
Than every private subject in my land:
My life hath been a loadstar unto them,
To guide them in the labyrinth of blame,
Thus I have taught them for to do amiss:
Then must I weep my friend for their amiss,
The fall of Niniuie is wrought by me:
I have maintained this City in her shame.
I have contemned the warnings from above .
I have upholden incest, rape, and spoil.
It is I that wrought thy sin, must weep thy sin.
O had I tears like to the silver streams,
That from the Alpine Mountains sweetly stream,
Or had I sighs the treasures of remorse,
As plentiful as olus hath blasts,
I then would tempt the heavens with my laments,
And pierce the throne of mercy by my sighs.

sp.speaker: K. Cil.
sp.l: Heavens are propitious unto faithful prayers.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: But after our repent, we must lament:
Lest that a worser mischief doth befall.
O pray, perhaps the Lord will pity us .
O God of truth both merciful and just,
Behold repentant men with piteous eyes,
We wail the life that we have led before.
O pardon Lord, O pity Niniuie.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: O pardon Lord, O pity Niniuie.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Let not the Infants dallying on the tent,
For fathers sins in judgment be oppressed.

sp.speaker: K. Cil.
sp.l: Let not the painful mothers big with child,
The innocents be punished for our sin.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: O pardon Lord, O pity Niniuie.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: O pardon Lord, O pity Niniuie.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: O Lord of heaven, the virgins weep to thee.
The covetous man sorry for his sin.
The Prince and poor, all pray before thy throne.
And wilt thou then be wroth with Niniuie?

sp.speaker: K. Cili.
sp.l: Give truce to prayer O king, and rest a space.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Give truce to prayers, when times require no truce?
No Princes no. Let all our subjects hie
Unto our temples, where on humbled knees,
I will expect some mercy from above.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: This is the day wherein the Lord hath said.
That Niniuie shall quite be overthrown.
This is the day of horror and mishap,
Fatal unto the cursed Niniuites.
These stately Towers shall in thy watery bounds,
Swift flowing Licas find their burials,
These palaces the pride of Assurs kings,
Shall be the bowers of desolation,
Where as the solitary bird shall sing,
And Tigers train their young ones to their nest.
O all ye nations bounded by the West,
Ye happy Isles, where Prophets do abound,
Ye Cities famous in the western world,
Make Niniuie a president for you.
Leave lewd desires, leave covetous delights.
Fly usury, let whoredom be exiled,
Lest you with Niniuie be overthrown.
Lo how the suns inflamed torch prevails,
Scorching the parched furrows of the earth.
Here will I sit me down and fix mine eye
Upon the ruins of yon wretched Town,
And lo a pleasant shade, a spreading vine,
To shelter Ionas in this sunny heat,
What means my God, the day is done end spent.
Lord shall my Prophecy be brought to naught?
When falls the fire? When will the judge be wroth?
I pray thee Lord remember what I said,
When I was yet within my country land,
Iehouah is too merciful I fear.
O let me fly before a Prophet fault,
For thou art merciful the Lord my God,
Full of compassion and sufferance,
And dost repent in taking punishment.
Why stays thy hand? O Lord first take my life,
Before my Prophecy be brought to noughts.
Ah he is wroth, behold the gladsome vine
That did defend me from the sunny heat,
Is withered quite, and swallowed by a Serpent.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Now furious Phlegon triumphs on my brows,
And heat prevails, and I am faint in heart.

sp.speaker: Angell.
sp.l: Art thou so angry Ionas tell me why?

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Iehouah, I with burning heat am plunged,
And shadowed only by a silly vine.
Behold a Serpent hath devoured it.
And lo the sun incensed by Eastern wind,
Afflicts me with Cariculer aspect,
Would God that I might die, for well I wot,
It were better I were dead, then rest alive.

sp.speaker: Angell.
sp.l: Ionas art thou so angry for the vine,

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Yea I am angry to the death my God.

sp.speaker: Angell.
sp.l: Thou hast compassion Ionas on a vine,
On which thou never labour didst bestow,
Thou never gavest it life or power to grow,
Bud suddenly it sprung and suddenly died.
And should not I have great compassion
On Niniuie the City of the Lord,
Wherein there are a hundred thousand souls,
And twenty thousand infants that ne wot
The right hand from the left, besides much cattle.
O Ionas look into their Temples now,
And see the true contrition of their King:
The subjects tears, the sinners true remorse.
Then from the Lord, proclaim a mercy day,
For he is pitiful as he is just.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: I go my God to finish thy command,
O who can tell the wonders of my God:
Or talk his praises with a fervent tongue.
He bringeth down to hell, and lifts to heaven.
He draws the yoke of bondage from the just,
And looks upon the Heathen with piteous eyes,
To him all praise and honour be ascribed.
O who can tell the wonders of my God,
He makes the infant to proclaim his truth,
The ass to speak, to save the Prophets life.
The earth and sea to yield increase for man.
Who can describe the compass of his power?
Or testify in terms his endless might?
My ravished sprite, o whither dost thou wend?
Go and proclaim the mercy of my God.
Relieve the careful hearted Niniuites
And as thou wert the messenger of death,
Go bring glad tidings of recovered grace.

body.stage: Enters Adam solus, with a bottle of beer in one shop, and a great peece of beefe in an other.

sp.p: Well goodman Ionas, I would you had never come from Jewry to this Country, you have made me look like a lean rib of roast beef, or like the picture of lent, painted upon a red herrings cob. Alas masters, we are commanded by the proclamation to fast and pray, by my troth I could prettily so, so, away with praying, but for fasting, why it is so contrary to my nature, that I had rather suffer a short hanging, than a long fasting. Mark me, the words be these. Thou shalt take no manner of food for so many days. I had as leave he should have said, thou shalt hang thyself for so many days. And yet in faith I need not find fault with the proclamation, for I have a buttery, and a pantry, and a kitchen, about me, for proof, Ecce signum, this right flop is my pantry, behold a manchet, this place is my kitchen, for lo a piece of beef. O let me repeat that sweet word again: For lo a piece of beef. This is my buttery, for see, see, my friends, to my great joy, a bottle of beer. Thus alas, I make shift to wear out this fasting, I drive away the time, but there go Searchers about to seek if any man breaks the Kings command. O here they be, in with your victuals Adam.

sp.speaker: 1. Searcher.
sp.p: How duly the men of Niniuie keep the proclamation, how are they armed to repentance? we have searched through the whole City and have not as yet found one that breaks the fast.

sp.speaker: 2. Sear.
sp.p: The sign of the more grace, but stay, here sits one methinks at his prayers, let us see who it is.

sp.speaker: 1. Sear.
sp.l: It is Adam the Smiths man, how now Adam.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: Trouble me not, thou shalt take no manner of food, but fast and pray.

sp.speaker: 1. Sear.
sp.p: How devoutly he sits at his orisons, but stay, methinks I feel a smell of some meat or bread about him.

sp.speaker: 2. Sear.
sp.p: So thinks me too, you sirrah, what victuals have you about you?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Victuals! O horrible blasphemy! Hinder me not of my prayer, nor drive me not into a choler, victuals! why hardest thou not the sentence, thou shalt take no food but fast and pray?

sp.speaker: 2. Sear.
sp.p: Truth so it should be, but methinks I smell meat about thee.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: About me my friends, these words are actions in the Case, about me, no, no: hang those gluttons that cannot fast and pray.

sp.speaker: 1. Sear.
sp.l: Well, for all your words, we must search you.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Search me, take heed what you do, my hose are my castles, it is burglary if you break ope a slop, no officer must lift up an iron hatch, take heed my slops are iron.

sp.speaker: 2. Sear.
sp.p: O villain, see how he hath gotten victuals, bread, beef, and beer, where the King commanded upon pain of death none should eat for so many days, no not the sucking infant.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Alas sir, this is nothing but a modicum nou necet vt medicus daret, why sir, a bit to comfort my stomach.

sp.speaker: 1. Sear.
sp.l: Villain thou shalt be hanged for it.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: These are your words, I shall be hanged for it, but first answer me to this question, how many days have we to fast still?

sp.speaker: 2. Sear.
sp.l: Five days.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: Five days, a long time, then I must be hanged?

sp.speaker: 1. Sear.
sp.l: Aye marry must thou.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: I am your man, I am for you sir, for I had rather be hanged, then abide so long a fast, what five days? come I will untruss, is your halter and the gallows, the ladder, and all such furniture in readiness?

sp.speaker: 1. Sear.
sp.l: I warrant thee, shalt want none of these.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: But hear you, must I be hanged?

sp.speaker: 1.Sear.
sp.l: Aye marry.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: And for eating of meat, then friends, know ye by these presents, I will eat up all my meat, and drink up all my drink, for it shall never be said, I was hanged with an empty stomach.

sp.speaker: 1.Sear.
sp.l: Come away knave, wilt thou stand feeding now?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: If you be hasty, hang yourself an hour while I come to you, for surely I will eat up my meat.

sp.speaker: 2.Sear.
sp.l: Come let us draw him away perforce.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: You say there is five days yet to fast, these are your words.

sp.speaker: 2.Sear.
sp.l: Aye sir.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: I am for you, come let us away, and yet let me be put in the Chronicles.

body.stage: Enter Ionas, Rasni, Aluida, kings of Cilicia, others royally atteded.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Come careful King, cast off thy mournful weeds,
Exchange thy cloudy looks to smoothed smiles,
Thy tears have pierced the piteous throne of grace,
Thy sighs like Immense pleasing to the Lord:
Have been peace offerings for thy former pride.
Rejoice and praise his name that gave thee peace.
And you fair Nymphs, ye lovely Niniuites,
Since you have wept and fasted for the Lord,
He graciously have tempered his revenge,
Beware henceforth to tempt him anymore,
Let not the niceness of your beauteous looks,
Engraft in you a high presuming mind,
For those that climb, he casteth to the ground,
And they that humble be, he lifts aloft.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Lowly I bend with awful bent of eye,
Before the dread Iehouah, God of host,
Despising all profane device of man,
Those lustful lures that whilom led awry,
My wanton eyes shall wound my heart no more:
And she whose youth in dalliance I abused,
Shall now at last become my wedlock mate.
Fair Aluida look not so woe begone:
If for thy sin thy sorrow do exceed,
Blessed be thou, come with thy holy band,
Let us knit a knot to salve our former shame.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: With blushing looks betokening my remorse,
I lowly yield my King to thy behest,
So as this man of God shall think it good.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Woman, amends may never come too late.
I will thou practise goodness, and virtuousness,
The God of heaven when sinners do repent,
Doth more rejoice than in ten thousand just.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Then witness holy Prophet our accord.

sp.speaker: Alui.
sp.l: Plight in the presence of the Lord thy God.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Blessed may you be, like to the flouring sheaves
That play with gentle winds in summer tide,
Like Olive branches let your children spread:
And as the Pines in lofty Libanon,
Or as the Kids that feed on Lepher plains,
So be the seed and offsprings of your loins,

body.stage: Enters the Vsurer, Gentleman, and Alcon.

sp.speaker: Vsurer.
sp.l: Come forth my friends, whom wittingly I wronged,
Before this man of God, receive your due,
Before our king I mean to make my peace.
Ionas, behold in sign of my remorse,
I here restore into these poor men's hands,
Their goods which I unjustly have retained,
And may the heavens so pardon my misdeeds,
As I am penitent for my offence.

sp.speaker: Thrasi.
sp.l: And what through want, from others I purloined,
Behold O King, I proffer forth thy throne.
To be restored to such as owe the same.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: A virtuous deed pleasing to God and man,
Would God all Cities drowned in like shame,
Would take example of these Niniuites.

sp.speaker: Rasni.
sp.l: Such be the fruits of Niniuies repent,
And such forever may our dealings be,
That he that called us home in height of sin,
May smile to see our hearty penitence.
Viceroys proclaim a fast unto the Lord,
Let Israel's God be honoured in our land.
Let all occasion of corruption die.
For who shall fault therein, shall suffer death.
Bear witness God, of my unfeigned zeal.
Come holy man, as thou shalt counsel me,
My Court and City shall reformed be.

sp.speaker: Ionas.
sp.l: Wend on in peace, and prosecute this course,
You Islanders on whom the milder air
Doth sweetly breath the balm of kind increase:
Whose lands are fattened with the dew of heaven,
And made more fruitful than Actean plains.
You whom delicious pleasures dandle soft:
Whose eyes are blinded with security,
Unmask yourselves, cast error clean aside.
O London, maiden of the mistress I will,
Wrapped in the folds and swathing clouts of shame.
In thee more sins than Niniuie contains.
Contempt of God, despite of reverend age.
Neglect of law, desire to wrong the poor:
Corruption, whoredom, drunkenness, and pride.
Swollen are thy brows with impudence and shame.
O proud adulterous glory of the West,
Thy neighbours burns, yet dost thou fear no fire.
Thy Preachers cry, yet dost thou stop thine ears.
The larum rings, yet sleepest thou secure.
London awake, for fear the Lord do frown,
I set a looking Glass before thine eyes.
O turn, O turn, with weeping to the Lord,
And think the prayers and virtues of thy Queen,
Defers the plague, which otherwise would fall.
Repent O London, lest for thine offence,
Thy shepherd fail, whom mighty God preserve,
That she may bide the pillar of his Church,
Against the storms of Romish Antichrist:
The hand of mercy overshed her head,
And let all faithful subjects say, Amen.
